loans.name: Ada

texts.es:
La señora Ada, pertenece al Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima”, Distrito de Juanjui, Provincia Mariscal Cáceres, Departamento de San Martín. Es Casada, tiene 59 años, 04 hijos, tres que aun dependen de ella.

Nos cuenta que se inicio con la venta de cosméticos desde hace muchos años atrás, gracias a las ganancias obtenidas  logró implementar su propio negocio de venta de abarrotes en su misma casa al viene dedicándose desde hace muchos años.

Con el primer préstamo que recibió logro implementar mejor su bodega, hoy sus vecinos y amigos ya le conocen y tiene mucha acogida, sus ventas le salen a pedir de boca y piensa seguir adelante y prosperar con otros negocios.

Con este préstamo de S/. 3,000.00, comprará abarrotes como: sacos de arroz y azúcar, paquetes de leches y aceites; gaseosas en paquetes de diferentes sabores y tamaños e insumos para la limpieza del hogar e higiene personal. Así de esta manera mantener a sus clientes satisfechos y contentos.

Se siente muy satisfecha con el trabajo que realiza, cree que vale el sacrificio para cumplir sus sueños y metas que tiene trazado en su vida. Así mismo agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por brindarle apoyo a ella y a  demás mujeres que quieren salir adelante.
texts.en:
Señora Ada belongs to the Communal Bank named "Santa Rosa de Lima", district of Juanjui, Mariscal Cáceres province, department of San Martin. She is married and 59 years old with 4 children, three of whom still depend on her for support. She tells us that she started with the sale of cosmetics many years ago. Thanks to the profits she obtained she managed to start her own convenience store business in her own home, to which she has been dedicated for many years. With the first loan that she received she was able to improve her store. Today her neighbors and friends know her well and she has much reknown. Her sales grow by word of mouth and she hopes to continue ahead and to prosper with other businesses. With this loan of 3,000 soles she will buy groceries such as: bags of rice and sugar, packages of milk and oils; carbonated water in packages of different flavors and sizes and supplies for cleaning the home and personal hygiene. In this manner she will keep her happy and satisfied clients. She feels very satisfied with the work that she does. She believes that it is worth the sacrifice to pursue her dreams and goals that she has planned for life. Thus she gives thanks the Manuela Ramos Movement for offering their support to her and to other women that want to do well.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy groceries to increase the products she offers in her store.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Dyeing cloth, commerce, and processing seafood

loans.name: Crescentia

texts.en:
Crescentia is married and lives in Ntabese Nkwen, a quarter in Bamenda, Cameroon. She has six children, three of whom are below fifteen years in age. Crescentia sells scourge eggs and cooked food in a private secondary school during lunch hour. With this loan, she plans to buy flour, eggs and other ingredients to make the food she sells. She has faced hardship and numerous challenges in life, such as the death of her first son and second daughter. There was a time when her entire family was sick. She has also lost two brothers who were very supportive of her and helped her take care of her family.

Crescentia has been a member of GHAPE since 2005, and this will be her fourth loan. She has been quite successful in the past with her business due to her location, the quality of her food, and her reasonable prices. She has a strong customer base and is confident that she will be able to increase her sales. Part of the profits from this loan will be used towards school fees for her children. The rest will be used for medication and for feeding her large family. She does not foresee a problem with her loan repayments, as they are quite small repayments every two weeks.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards empowerment of the poor, and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account. Most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff, and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Buying flour, eggs and other ingredients.

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta R. is already 39 years old. She is engage in managing a rolling store business for many years. She uses a motorcycle in selling the different goods such vegetables, meat, fish, etc. in their village of Sto.Nińo Aurora, Isabela and nearby villages. Prior to having a motorcycle that is being of big help in her rolling business, Violeta first suffer to roam her vending products by her bare foot for 18 years. She was glad that through her patience in the business, she is able to purchase an installment motorcycle for her business. 
At the moment, Violeta enjoys selling her goods in their village and even reach other villages to sell her products. Because of this expansion of her business, her goods usually are being sold out without even reaching out some of her customers thus wanted to request for additional business capital amounting to PHP20, 000 from KIVA lenders to further meet her customers requests and demands for she used to believe that customers. She hopes someday to become successful in the business and also to improve their living condition. It is really of great help said Violeta.

loans.use: additional business capital

loans.name: Marta Eugenia

texts.es:
Marta Eugenia S. Viquez es una señora de 48 años de edad quien vive con su esposo y sus dos hijos en una comunidad llamada El Saíno de Pital localizada en la provincia de Alajuela; cuyas principales actividades productivas son la ganadería y la agricultura, donde destaca el cultivo de la piña; siendo estas comercializadas principalmente en los mercados internacionales.  Por esta razón, el desarrollo de la comunidad ha venido creciendo en los últimos años generando una mayor demanda de productos y servicios, lo que ayuda a mitigar el efecto de inmigración.

Doña Marta se ha dedicado la mayor parte de su vida a las labores del hogar y también asistiendo a su esposo en agricultura, pero hace poco tiempo tuvo la idea de crear una pulpería (tiendita de abarrotes) para vender productos básicos a sus vecinos en su propia casa. Su objetivo es tener una actividad económica rentable que la ayude a mejorar su calidad de vida. Ella comenta que al tener el negocio en su propia casa no tiene que pagar alquiler lo cual le ayuda a que el negocio salga adelante.

Actualmente ella necesita un préstamo por ¢685.000(seiscientos ochenta y cinco mil colones) para comprar mercadería que pueda vender y así iniciar su negocio. Específicamente comprará abarrotes básicos como arroz, frijoles, verduras, productos enlatados, refrescos, jabón, golosinas y todo lo que se refiere a la canasta básica del costarricense que vive en las zonas rurales. Doña Marta comenta que el servicio que ella brindará es muy importante ya que no existen otras pulperías muy cerca de la zona  por lo tanto espera tener bastantes clientes. 

Doña Marta es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal Luz del Futuro Saino, una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su primer  préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico. También destaca que gracias a este tipo de organizaciones y medios facilitadores de crédito puede dedicar más tiempo a las actividades productivas.
texts.en:
Marta Eugenia S. Viquez, 48, lives with her husband and their two children in the El Saíno de Pital community, which is located in the Alajuela province. Its principle productive activities are livestock and farming. Cultivating pineapples stands out because these are mainly sold in international markets. For that reason, the community development has been growing in the last few years. This has generated a greater demand for products and services, which help to mitigate the effect of immigration. Marta has devoted the greater part of her life to taking care of her home. She also helps her husband with the farming. But, a little while ago she had the idea to have a mini- market (a small grocery store) to be able to sell, in her own house, basic products to her neighbors. Her objective is to have a profitable economic activity to help improve her quality of life. She says that having the business in her own house means she does not have to pay rent, which will help her get ahead in her business. She currently needs a loan for ¢685.000 (six hundred eighty five thousand colones) to buy merchandise to sell. That way she can start her business. Specifically, she will buy basic groceries like rice, beans, vegetables, canned goods, soft drinks, soap, sweets, and everything that is referred to as the basic basket for Costa Ricans who live in the rural areas. Marta says that the service she will offer is very important because there are no other mini-markets nearby in the region. Therefore, she expects to have plenty of customers. Marta is a member of the Futuro Saino Communal Credit Union, which of one of the 100 members of EDESA in Costa Rica. This will be her first loan, and she hopes to continue growing on a personal and economic level. She also points out that thanks to this type of organization and their methods for facilitating loans, she can spend more time on productive activities.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy inventory and merchandise

loans.name: Taroob

texts.en:
Taroob is a women who started her business ten years ago. She started with only 3 sheep and when she received a loan from FATEN amounting to 3000 USD, she used the loan to buy more goats/sheep. Now she has more than 20 sheep and goats, and she has established a small mini-market. She has already repaid this loan in full, and now she needs 2000 USD to buy more goats and to acquire more products for her shop.

Taroob is married, her husband is a teacher in a public school; she has four children, three of them still at school while the fourth is at the university. Her husband and eldest child help her manage the two businesses. She is very happy to have established a business of her own and to help her family to have better life.

Taroob appears in the picture in her barn.

loans.use: Buy goats and sheep and develop her mini-market

loans.name: Muhabat

texts.en:
Muhabat K. is 32 years old. She is married and has 4 children.

She started her own business 5 years ago because her husband was unemployed at the time. Muhabat sells confections like candies, cookies and pastries in the local market. The income she generates allows Muhabat to support her family. Muhabat dreams of educating all of her children through higher education.

Today, she is requesting 6000 TJS to purchase goods to increase her range of products. She plans to spend the income she generates on the well being of her family as well as her children's education.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International:

Tajikistan is known for its rich history. It was once a key post along the Silk Road at the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

However, Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History:

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients have a viable business opportunity. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase goods to offer more types of confections

loans.name: Elita

texts.en:
This is Elita A., a 49-year-old entrepreneur from Silang, Cavite. She hails from a farming family and is married to Patricio, 64, a bank employee. Three of their children are now in college, while one is in high school.

Elita owns and manages a computer shop catering to Internet surfers, gamers and students. She has been in this business for eight years and has an employee to assist her. She also has a general store, and when time permits, she also provides massage therapy. Elita, who makes P30,000 a month, enjoys dealing with customers of all ages and from different walks of life. Customer traffic peaks on weekends, she says.

She is now on her ninth loan cycle with the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. Currently in need of funds to buy additional computer units for the expansion of her computer center and to upgrade some of her PC units, Elita is requesting a loan of P21,000.00 with CCT. She hopes to expand her computer center so she can save her earnings to enable all of her children to complete their education.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ. CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase additional computer units

loans.name: Hernestina

texts.es:
Nuestra socia HERNESTINA es madre soltera, es natural de la ciudad de Cusco y pertenece al banco comunal “PATRON SANTIAGO DE SANTIAGO” de la Asociación Arariwa. La socia tiene una hija que se llama Elizabeth que tiene 18 años y se esta preparando para ingresar a la universidad.   
       
La socia alterna sus actividades del hogar con la venta de frutas y verduras. Ella tiene su stand en el mercado de “Cascaparo” de la ciudad del Cusco. Ya son varios años con el negocio y le ha ido muy bien gracias a todo el empeño que pone en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre, trabajadora y emprendedora que saca adelante a su familia. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar más frutas y verduras como cebollas, repollos, lechugas y muchas más. 
   
La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Hernestina is a single mother who was born in the city of Cusco. She belongs to the Arariwa Association's "Patron Santiago de Santiago" communal bank. She has a daughter, Elizabeth, who is 18 years old and preparing to enter the university. Hernestina divides her time between her work at home and her business selling fruits and vegetables. She has a stand in Cusco's “Cascaparo” market. She has operated this business for several years, and it has gone very well for her, thanks for all of the effort and dedication she puts into her work. She is a hardworking and entrepreneurial mother who is helping her family get ahead. She needs a loan to buy more fruits and vegetables, such as onions, cabbage, lettuce, and much more. She is grateful for the opportunity provided to her in this manner, and she is committed to making her payments on schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing fruits and vegetables such as onions, cabbage, lettuce, etc.

loans.name: San Roque Group

texts.es:
Para la formación del comité inicio  la señora Leticia Silva, quien vive en el barrio San Roque de C.D.E, ella contacto con sus vecinas y amigas para formar el comité en la zona.
El comité se denomina “San Roque”en honor al nombre del barrio de su comunidad, está constituido  por 18  señoras muy activas y solidarias todas de la mism zona.
Las señoras retiran un crédito de Gs 300.000 a 500.000 Gs están en el Segundo Ciclo 
El Crédito destinara a sus respectivas actividades, compra de mercaderías  y artículos de primera necesidad para su posterior venta.

texts.en:
Leticia Silva, who lives in the San Roque de C.D.E neighborhood, organized her neighbors and friends into the area committee. The committee is called “San Roque” in honor of their neighborhood’s name. It is made up of 18, very active and united women from the same area. They are requesting funds that range from Gs.300.000 o Gs. 500.000; they are in their second cycle. The funds will be used in their respective commercial activities, to buy merchandise and basic needs items to sell. 1. Amanda R., grocery store; 2. Graciela P., fruit sales; 3. María Torrez, clothing sales; 4. Lucia B., eggs and sugar sales; 5. Estelvina R., clothing sales; 6. Sandra B., clothing sales; 7. Máxima R., seamstress; 8. Daily González, beauty salon; 9. Leidy Cabañas, Internet-Phone booths; 10. Cinthya U., clothing sales; 11. Nimia R., grocery store; 12. Guillermina G., empanada (turnovers) sales; 13. Felicia S., chipas (a variety of breads made with manioc or corn flour); 14. Alba A., clothing sales; 15. Fátima D., clothing sales; 16. Marta R., cosmetics sales; 17. Nancy R., Copetín (informal snack bars); 18. Viviana C., underwear sales.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise and work tools according to each member's commercial activity such as: for the grocery store (bakery goods, milk, basic needs items), for the beauty salon (diffusers, hair straighteners), etc.

loans.name: Savet

texts.en:
Mrs. Savet C., 45, and her husband, Mr. Bunthoeun Hul, 47, were married in 1990 and have four children: 3 sons are in school and 1 daughter weaves silk at home. The family is living on an Island of the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Savet is a silk-weaver, while her husband is a farmer. She obtained previous loans from Kiva through Maxima and is now requesting another loan of $600 to purchase silk materials for her weaving business. Also, she will use part of her loan to help provide capital for her husband in his farming business.

loans.use: To buy silk materials for her weaving business and to provide capital for her husband's farm

loans.name: Ruth Lisseth

texts.es:
Ruth tiene 29 años, es soltera y pertenece al banco comunal “Las hijas de Maria” de la Asociación Arariwa. Ruth trabaja como docente desde hace 4 años en el colegio “Virgen de Fátima” en la ciudad del Cusco. La socia actualmente se encuentra preparándose para rendir el examen del Concurso Público de Contrato de Docente  2010. La socia nos cuenta que por las tardes hace reforzamientos de los cursos de matemáticas, ciencias lingüísticas, etc. a alumnos de bajo rendimiento escolar.  Ruth requiere el préstamo para la matricularse para poder rendir el examen del concurso público. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Ruth is 29 years old, she is single and belongs to the borrowing group "The Daughters of Maria" with Asociación Arariwa. Ruth has worked as a teacher for four years at the "Virgen of Fátima" high school in the city of Cusco. She is currently preparing to take the Public Teacher Contract exam for 2010. Ruth said that in the afternoons she tutors students who are behind in the subjects of mathmaticas, linguistic sciences, etc. Ruth needs this to be able to register for the exam. Ruth is grateful for the opportunity that this loan brings and is committed to complete her repayments according to the repayment plan.

Translated from Spanish by Kelly McKinnon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Ruth needs this loan to register for a teachers exam

loans.name: Julio Cesar

texts.es:
El  señor Julio S. labora en un centro de capacitación profesional en Managua donde a diario busca la manera de cómo salir adelante en su labor para continuar llevando el sustento a su habitación donde tiene dos hijos a su cargo y en edad escolar.

El crédito solicitado es para invertir en la compra de materiales de construcción como: cemento, arena, hierro y mano de obra para la construcción de un muro en la parte del patio de su casa de habitación para  darle una mejor condición de vida a su familia que tanto depende de él.
texts.en:
Mr. Julio S. works at a vocational training center in Managua. Everyday he goes to work he works hard to be able to provide for his home and family. Julio is a father of school age children. The loan he has requested will be used to invest in the purchase of construction materials like cement, sand, tools and labor to build a wall around his patio. This will improve the quality of life of Julio's family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Pay for materials & labor to build a security wall

loans.name: Nguyễn's Group

texts.en:
L. Nguyễn Thị (20211040003) is a 29-year-old female living in the town of Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  L. is the group leader of a two-member group loan offered by SEDA.  While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is Tiên Trà 1 - Nhóm 01 (Nhóm 01).


L. is married and has two infant-aged children.  To making a living, L. owns & operates a specialized retail store selling metal & metal-related products in the local community.  L. has been engaged in this business for over eight years and earns approximately 2,000,000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2008, L. joined SEDA to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  L. has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4,256,000 VND from SEDA.  This previous loan was used to invest in expanding the business.  She is now requesting a new loan of 7,840,000 VND, which will be used to purchase new equipment & tools to expand the business.  The loan will be the third loan taken out by the borrower from SEDA.  L. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nguyễn Thị Thủy (20211040005) is a 43-year-old female who is requesting a 6,048,000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About SEDA:

The mission of SEDA (Center of Small Enterprise Development Assistance) is to provide microfinance services to the low-income and disadvantaged people in rural areas of Hanoi and the Northern provinces of Vietnam.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


L. Nguyễn Thị (20211040003) là 29 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Yên Phong - Bắc Ninh.  L. là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 2 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là Tiên Trà 1 - Nhóm 01 (Nhóm 01).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ buôn bán các sản phẩm kim loại & có L. quan đến kim loại trong cộng đồng địa phương.  L. thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 8 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, L. kiếm được khoảng 2.000.000 VND.  Vào 2008, L. đã tham gia SEDA để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  L. đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 4.256.000 VND từ SEDA.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư mở rộng công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7.840.000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 3rd khoản vay của người vay từ SEDA.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nguyễn Thị Thủy (20211040005) là 43 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 6.048.000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về SEDA:

Nhiệm vụ của SEDA (Trung Tâm hỗ Trợ Phát Triển các Doanh Nghiệp Nhỏ) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính vi mô cho những người có thu nhập thấp và kém may mắn trong các vùng nông thôn tại Hà Nội và các tỉnh phía Bắc Việt Nam


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  .

loans.use: To purchase new equipment & tools to expand the business

loans.name: Armando Jorge

texts.pt:
Armando Jorge Xirinda nasceu no Distrito da Manhiça, Província de Maputo, sul de Moçambique tem 41 anos de idade casado e pai de 4 filhos de 10, 07 e dois de 14 anos de idade, todos vão a escola. Fez 10ą classe não continuou devido a falta de condições financeiras. Vive na casa própria com a sua família e sustenta 1 sobrinho que vive com ele.
Saiu do Distrito da Manhaça para o Distrito de Boane ainda na Província de Maputo com a sua família, refugiando se da guerra de desestabilizava que assolou o pais durante a década 80. Tem um negocio próprio há mais de 4 anos, não possui nenhum empregado e vende mais mantas, micro-ondas, arcondicionados, geleiras e outros. Consegue um rendimento mensal de cerca de 20.000.00mt, que aplica nas despesas de casa e ainda poupa algum na sua conta bancária.
Nunca teve empréstimo em outros bancos, conheceu a Hluvuku através de amigos que já são clientes desta instituição. Este é o seu 2º empréstimo no valor de 25.000.00mt, com o qual pretende comprar produtos (banheira, geleira, micro onda e outros) para aumentar a quantidade do seu produto.
Compromete se a pagar devidamente este crédito para poder aceder a outros, no futuro gostaria de solicitar mais empréstimos para expandir o seu negócio.
texts.en:
Armando Jorge Xirinda was born in the district of Manhiça, Maputo Province, in southern Mozambique. He is 41 years old and married. He is the father of a 17-year-old, two 14-year-olds, and a 10-year-old, all of whom attend school. He only went to school through the 10th grade, and wasn't able to continue because of his family's difficult financial circumstances. He lives in his own house with his family, and also supports a nephew who lives with them. He and his family left Manhiça for Boane, also in Maputo Province, fleeing the war that devastated the country during the '80s. He's had his own business for more than four years. He doesn't have any employees, and sells blankets, microwaves, air conditioners, refrigerators, etc. He earns about 20,000 meticals a month, which is enough to cover household expenses with a little left over to keep in his savings account. He's never received loans from other banks. He learned about Hvuluku through friends who are also Hvuluku clients. This is his second loan, in the amount of 25,000 meticals, which he will use to buy products (bathtubs, refrigerators, microwaves, etc.) to increase the amount of merchandise he carries. He's committed to paying this loan off on time so that in the future he'll be eligible for others. He'd like to request additional loans to expand his business.

Translated from Portuguese by Andrea Rosenberg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying and selling refrigerators, microwaves, etc.

loans.name: Maria Delmira

texts.es:
María Delmira es una madre de familia de 24 años de edad que vive junto a su esposo y sus dos hijos en el sector Ciudad de Dios del distrito de San José, provincia de Lambayeque, ubicado a 20 minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica desde hace cuatro años a la crianza y venta de animales menores (aves de corral y cuyes) en su vivienda. Ella los compra cuando tienen pocos dias de nacidos para criarlos, engordarlos y luego venderlos a los negociantes que visitan la zona regularmente. Con este negocio ella apoya al sostenimiento de su familia ya que los ingresos que percibe su esposo como obrero de la municipalidad del distrito no son suficientes para sostener la economía del hogar.

María Delmira desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de más animales para criarlos y así captar más ingresos, por eso se encuentra solicitando por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 500 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su meta trazada.

María Delmira es una mujer trabajadora y entregada a su familia, todos los esfuerzos y acciones que realiza tienen la finalidad de progresar y salir adelante. Sus vecinos la estiman mucho y la consideran una mujer de confianza.
texts.en:
María Delmira, 24, lives with her husband and two children in the Ciudad de Dios neighborhood of San José district, Lambayeque province, located 20 minutes from the city of Chiclayo. For the last four years she has raised small farm animals (barnyard fowl and guinea pigs) in her yard. She buys them when they are just a few days old and raises them for later sale to merchants that visit the area regularly. This business helps her to support the family because the income her husband earns as a laborer for the city is not sufficient to support the household. María Delmira wants to increase her business buying more animals to raise so that she can earn higher income. For this reason, she is calling upon Edpyme Alternativa, for the first time, to request a 500 new sol loan to help her reach this goal. María Delmira is a hard-working woman who is dedicated to her family; all her efforts and actions are aimed at her family’s success and progress. Her neighbors hold her in high regard and consider her to be trustworthy.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy small farm animals.

location.town: Ciudad de Dios - San José - Lambayeque

loans.name: Hab

texts.en: Mrs. Hab V., 56, sells fresh fish that she buys from suppliers or fishermen. She sells to her neighbors around the community. She is a widow, blessed with six children, four of whom are married and live separately, while the others are single. Hab V. has a few sons who sometimes fish for a profit. In order to earn extra revenue and to make her business more successful, Hab V. would like to request a loan to accrue capital for her business. By using a loan, Hab V. is hopeful that she will get more money to ensure a better standard of living for her family.

loans.use: to accrue capital for her fish business

loans.name: Yorleny

texts.es: Yorleny S. E., tiene la edad de 34 años, está casado, y vive con su esposo y sus 2 hijos que son mayor prioridad. El crédito lo quiere para siembra y para asistir su finca, específicamente para el cultivo de café, la idea es comprar unas matas de café para sembrar, y además comprar el abono y el fertilizante. Desea darle el adecuado mantenimiento al cultivo de café para lograr una mejor calidad y para obtener el mayor ingreso posible cuando sea tiempo de cosecha. Es la primera vez que realiza un crédito con FUDECOSUR y está muy contenta con las facilidades que se le brindaron. Doña Yorleny también trabaja desde hace varios años en la agricultura. Ella espera en un futuro brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida y una mayor estabilidad económica, y de poder seguir creciendo como persona y como productora.
texts.en:
Yorleny S. E. is 34 years old. She is married and lives with her husband and two children, who are her main priority. She wants the loan to plant and help her farm, specifically in growing coffee. The idea is to buy more coffee bushes to plant, as well as to buy organic and chemical fertilizer. She wants to have good maintainance of the coffee plants in order to have better quality and obtain the best income possible at harvest time. This is the first time that she has had a loan with FUDECOSUR and she is very happy with the opportunities they have given her. Yorleny has also worked for several years in agriculture. In the future, she hopes to offer her family a better quality of life and greater financial stability and to be able to keep growing as a person and as a farmer.

Translated from Spanish by Ellen Donohue, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Planting and assistance with growing coffee

loans.name: Bwavu Mpologoma W/g, Mpigi Group

texts.en:
S. Christine is a happily married woman with five children, two of whom are in school. 48-year-old Christine is the perfect personification of hard work. She has, for the last fourteen years, been multi-tasking, plying her produce sales and grocery business in Mpigi Township. Before she ventured into this business, she was inclined to low-key subsistence farming.

Throughout these years of operating, Christine has painstakingly taken measures aimed at getting into her customers good graces. She attributes her good customer handling line of operation as one of the reasons for her business’s longevity. She is optimistic the future will be even brighter on the acquisition of this loan.

Currently Christine makes weekly profits totaling up to 40,000 shillings. With this loan, she is intent on expanding her business. She wants to buy more of the produce that is in high favor with most of her clientele like maize, avocados, tomatoes, apples, and cassava.

loans.use: To purchase more foods to sell like cassava, tomatoes and maize

loans.name: Elvira

texts.es: Elvira, de 52 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en su casa propia junto a su esposo y su pequeña hija Mery.Elvira tiene una pequeña tienda instalada en una carreta ambulante, donde  vende golosinas  y letreros, sus clientes son sus vecinos. Además su esposo es experto en el pintado de letreros, cada una de las inscripciones, mencionan los recorridos de los buses, y los compradores de estos letreros, son los chóferes y ayudantes de las líneas que circulan cerca. Anteriormente ella y su esposo pintaban estos letreros, pero hoy en día, por las mañanas se dedica solo a la compra de sus golosinas, para que su carreta esté bien surtida y muy llamativa para los clientes. Es así que lleva 5 años con esta labor, aunque siente que su negocio es algo tedioso; no se queja porque tiene buenas ganancias económicas. Su mayor anhelo es ampliar su negocio y después quiere adquirir un Kiosco fijo, para que su tienda sea más estable.Este es su octavo préstamo que tiene con MFP, y sabe que el crédito le será muy beneficioso para aumentar su capital de trabajo, por lo que se compromete a pagar sus cuotas puntualmente, y en su grupo de trabajo  es reconocida por su seriedad.Elvira tiene planeado invertir  el dinero solicitado en la compra de mayor cantidad de  golosinas, pinturas acrílicas, para mejorar su negocio, y dice que si le sobra algo del dinero lo invertirá en el mejoramiento de su carreta.
texts.en:
Elvira, age 52, is a very hard-working woman. She lives in her own house together with her husband and her young daughter, Mery. Elvira has a little store installed on a mobile cart, from which she sells snacks and signs. Her neighbors are her customers. Her husband is an expert in painting signs. The inscriptions mention the bus routes, and the people who buy these signs are the drivers and assistants on the bus lines serving the area. Previously, she and her husband both painted the signs, but now Elvira dedicates herself in the mornings to buying her snacks, to make sure her wagon will be well-stocked and attractive to her customers. She has done this work for 5 years; although she feels that the business can be a bit tedious, she doesn't complain, because she obtains good economic returns. Her greatest desire is to expand her business and later to acquire a permanent kiosk, so that her store will be more stable. This is her eighth loan with MFP, and she knows that it will benefit her greatly by increasing her working capital. She is committed to making her payments on time, and she is known within her work group for being serious and responsible. Elvira plans to invest the funds she is requesting in buying a larger quantity of snacks, as well as acrylic paints, to improve her business, and she says that if there is any money left over, she will invest it in improving her wagon.

Translated from Spanish by Patricia Linderman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying merchandise and paint that she needs to improve her business

loans.name: Juan Carlos

texts.es:
El señor Juan Carlos T. tiene 22 años vive  con su esposa hace tres años, vive en la localidad de Tiraque del  Departamento de Cochabamba.

Juan Carlos a estudiado hasta segundo medio (secundaria) y trabaja en Tiraque al sur este del Departamento de Cochabamba a 50 km aproximadamente. El trabaja en construcción como  albañil, mientras la esposa se dedica a trabajos agrícolas en su comunidad donde siembra papa, haba y zanahoria un setenta por ciento vende al mercado y el resto para el consumo familiar.

El señor Juan Carlos y su esposa están solicitando un Crédito para comprar ganado de gorde y hacer  negocio, ósea el objetivo es comprar ganados terneros criarlos hasta que crescan un pocco y venderlos mas caros, de esa manera incrementar sus ingresos y mejorar sus condiciones de vida en el futuro.
texts.en:
Juan Carlos T., age 22, lives with his wife of three years in Tiraque in the Cochabamba department. Juan Carlos went to school as far as high school. He works in Tiraque, which is approximately 50 kilometers to the south in the Cochabamba department. He works in construction as a bricklayer. His wife devotes herself to farming work in their community. They plant potatoes, beans, and carrots. They sell 70% of what they grow, and the rest is for family consumption. Juan Carlos and his wife are requesting a loan to buy livestock to fatten in order to start a business. In other words, their objective is to buy calves to fatten. They will raise them until they grow a bit, and then they will sell them for more money. That way they will increase their income and improve their life conditions in the future.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy livestock to fatten

loans.name: Emma

texts.en:
45-year-old Emma B. is from the town of Sta. Josefa. She is married and has an eleven-year-old child. Emma owns and operates a general store. She sells both food & daily use products in the local community. She also owns a rice farm, which her husband manages. They sell their harvest at their store and to their local market. She has been doing this for over ten years now.

Emma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to do business. Emma has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Emma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) which will be used to purchase additional products to sell at the store as well as inputs for the rice farm. This loan will be the fourth loan taken out by Emma from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years. Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines. In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring. CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but additionally savings, insurance, and training which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: purchasing store inventory and farm inputs

loans.name: Erdene-Oyun

texts.en: Erdene-Oyun T. is 27 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hovd province, western Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger – a traditional housing tent. Her husband works for a local brick-manufacturing company. Erdene-Oyun manages a food trading business in her town. She started her business in 2008 and has used her earnings to purchase a fridge. She is requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to purchase more food products to sell at retail prices.

loans.use: To purchase more food products for resale

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua Y. is divorced and has three children. She sells plantains, cassava, palm fruits, and bagged charcoal at Takoradi. Efua uses her income to educate and feed her children. Efua will add the money to her initial capital to buy other foodstuffs for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Efua plans to save to invest in her children’s education.

loans.use: buy other varieties of foodstuffs for resale

loans.name: Nos

texts.en: Nos S. R., 40, is a fish seller who started her business more than nine years ago. She has a partner in her husband who works as a domestic carpenter. The couple has been married many years and they have three young school-aged children. Nos S. R. always uses her old motorcycle to deliver fish to the market. Nos S. R. is running her business well because she has skills in communication which she uses with her customers. However, her income is low as her business has low capacity due to insufficient financial capital. Nos S. R. wishes to have more money to increase her capital which will allow her to improve her profits. This is why she has decided to ask for a Kiva loan.

loans.use: To increase her capital.

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en: Mylene D. C. is from the village of San Lorenzo, Ilagan, Isabela. She is 35 years old and is married with two school-aged children. Mylene owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 2,200 PHP a month. In 2009, Mylene joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Mylene is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase pig feed and other supplies. This loan will be her 4th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase pig feed and other supplies

loans.name: Saranga Group

texts.en:
Daines E. is in her mid-twenties and is married. Since 2009, she has been running her own beauty salon. The salon is open between 8 a.m. and 9 p.m. and earns Daines a good monthly profit. 

This will be Daines' second Motisha loan with Tujijenge Tanzania. A Mothisha loan is a product offered by Tujijenge Tanzania that allows borrowers with good credit ratings to pay back their original loans faster and receive extra money before their original loan term has ended. Daines used her previous loan, which she has successfully repaid, to buy a hair dryer. With this new loan, Daines aims to buy new salon equipment for her business. Her dream is to one day own the most popular salon in the area.

Daines will share this loan with her loan group Saranga, which totals 11 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for repaying the loans.

In the photo, Daines is standing in the back row, third from the left in the red and orange dress.

loans.use: Buy new salon equipment

loans.name: Elaine

texts.en:
Elaine M., from the village of Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan de Oro City, is 45 years old, widowed and has five grown children. To make a living, Elaine owns and operates a business venture buying and selling boiled duck eggs or balot in the local community. Engaged in her business for over 15 years, she earns approximately 10000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Elaine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having repaid her previous loan of 4000 PHP from HSPFI that was used to purchase additional products to sell, she is now requesting her second loan for 7000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. Elaine plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her enterprise.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

location.town: Villa Verde, Balulang, Cagayan De Oro, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Jovel

texts.en:
Jovel P. is from the town of Banga. He is 41 years old. Jovel is married. To make a living, Jovel owns & operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He also plants vegetables like squash. Jovel wants to be a good husband and father. He says he wants to provide for all his family's needs and make them happy.

Jovel joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jovel has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Jovel is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve his business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more posters for resale

loans.name: Mat

texts.en:
Mat D., 27 years old, owns a small house and a grocery shop, where she sells many items, including cooking ingredients, sweets, soft drinks, and plastic products. Mat D. retails her inventory to people who are passing by and are also to neighbors who live near her house. She has been running her grocery store for a long time and earns an average of $6 a day. 

To making additional income, she also feeds a few chickens behind her house. Her husband is a local fisherman. This couple now lives with two children who go to school. 

Mat D. has applied for a loan from HKL, a Kiva field partner, to purchase additional chickens to raise.

loans.use: To purchase additional chickens to raise

loans.name: Patricia

texts.en: Patricia C. sells groceries and cosmetics at Akotokyir, near Abura. She is a single parent taking care of a child. She responsibly sees to the well-being of her family.  Her loan will be used to expand her grocery store. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save towards the education of her child.

loans.use: To expand her grocery store

loans.name: Jesus

texts.en:
Originally from Cuba, Jesus was employed at a corporate cleaning service but with the birth of his 19-month-old daughter, he decided that it was time to take his financial future into this own hands. He is currently the manager of his own night cleaning service. With the help of his wife, he has begun to build a reputable cleaning service. Together they have worked hard to build the number of clients the business services and improve the quality of their service. 

With this loan from ACCION USA , Jesus will be paying franchising fees for his business and truly establishing himself as his own boss. This will also enable him to solidify his credit history for the future when he is finally able to expand his business. 

Jesus’ hope is that he will be able to grow his business enough that he can quit his second job as an airport driver and spend more time with his growing family. Beyond supporting his family Jesus also wants to be able have a strong reputation in his community as a formidable businessman. 


About U.S. Microfinance and ACCION USA:
An estimated ten million small businesses in the U.S. face difficulty obtaining loans from traditional banks, even prior to the current “credit crisis”. Microfinance institutions like ACCION USA support these “unbanked” small businesses by giving them access to fairly priced capital and business education. Small businesses also help stabilize low- to moderate-income neighborhoods and rebuild our economy through income growth and job creation. Self-employment provides workers with a way to increase their incomes, support their families, and strengthen their communities. The need for support of small businesses in the U.S. is great, and it is one that ACCION USA has been striving to meet since 1991.

loans.use: To finance his nighttime cleaning venture

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase building materials

loans.name: Morelia Group

texts.es:
María Miguelita Pérez Raimundo, vive en la Ribera Morelia, municipio de coapilla estado de Chiapas México, es soltera  y estudia la preparatoria abierta.
            
              El préstamo que ha solicitado lo invertirá en la compra de materiales para su taller  de costura, como son: sierres, cortes, botones, hilo, entre otros,  en esta actividad lleva  ocho años desde que salió de la secundaria se dedica a esta actividad en que le va bien.

             Desde que tenía quince años ella practica este trabajo y aprendió por los cursos que dan en la secundaria que se llama corte y confección lo que gusto y  le da gracias a dios por haber aprendido ya que hoy es lo que lo saca de apuros en algunos gatos generados.

             De la ganancia de cada vestido u otra costura lo ahorra  para comprar mar materia y seguir trabajando con la costura que tanto le gusta  y asa poder pagar la colegiatura en la escuela.

              Lo que más desea es que logre terminar su preparatoria y seguir adelanté para tener su propio taller de donde pueda depender más adelante con su familia.

          Se integro al grupo por su mamá la señora Bertha quien formo el grupo y lleva el nombre de Morelia la razón del nombre  es porque  así se llama donde se integra el grupo.

      Las personas que integran el grupo son tres mujeres y son las siguientes:

     Bertha R. Pérez: invirtió el préstamo en la compra de mercancía para surtir su tienda de abarrotes, como son: azúcar, aceite, yogurt, entre otros.

    Norma Esperanza Vázquez Gómez: invirtió el préstamo en la compra  de materiales como son sierres, botones, hilos, entre otros para su taller de costura.

    María Miguelita pereza Raimundo: invirtió el préstamo en la compra de materiales para su taller de costura, donde elabora: vestidos, blusas, pantalones, entre otros.
texts.en:
María Miguelita Pérez Raimundo lives in Ribera Morelia, municipality of Coapilla, state of Chiapas, Mexico. She is single and goes to night school.

The loan she has requested will be used to purchase materials for her sewing business, such as zippers, scissors, buttons, thread, etc. She has been in this business for eight years since she finished high school. She does this business and it is going well.

Since she was 15 years old, she practiced sewing and learned it in classes through her high school, called tailoring and dressmaking. She like them, and she thanks God for having learned because now it gets her out of a lot of messes that come up.

She saves the profits she makes on each dress or item to buy more material and keep working as a seamstress because she likes it so much. This is how she is able to pay for her college classes.

She most wants to finish school and succeed in having her own seam shop where she will be able to help her family.

She became a part of this group by way of her mother, Bertha, who started the group and named it Morelia. The reason for this name is because that is the name of the place where the group started.

There are three women who make up the group. They are:

Bertha R. Pérez: She used this loan to purchase merchandise to stock her grocery store, such as sugar, oil, yogurt, etc.

Norma Esperanza Vázquez Gómez: She used this loan to buy materials such as zippers, buttons, thread, etc. for her sewing business.

María Miguelita P. Raimundo: She used the loan to buy materials for her seam shop where she makes dresses, blouses, slacks, etc.

loans.use: The purchase of materials to make clothes, such as dresses, blouses, and slacks. They will buy buttons, zippers, thread, etc.

loans.name: Piedragacha Group

texts.es: Esta foto fue tomada en la casa de la señora Umbelina, una integrante del grupo piedra gacha,que esta ubicado en el estado de VeraC., en la foto se ve a todas las integrantes del grupo, ella se dedica a la venta de antojitos que inicio hace 2 años, solicita el prestamo para ampliar su local y tener mayor clientela, sus vecinos la catalogan como una persona trabajadora, al momento de solicitar el prestamo se siente muy contenta, ella tiene 54 años, estudió la preparatoria, es casada y tiene un hijo. Quiere este crédito para ampliar su negocio, también espera que sus ventas e ingresos aumenten. Esther S. es la presidenta del grupo y tiene 21 años, estudió la secundaria, es casada y tiene 2 hijos, ella se dedica a la venta de calzado que inicio hace 1 año, solicita el prestamo para incrementar su crédito en la zapateria, el grupo esta conformado por 9 integrantes y es la primera vez que solicitan un crédito
texts.en:
This photo was taken at Umbelina’s house, a member of the Piedra Gacha group, which is located in the state of VeraC..  In the photo one can see all the members of the group.  

She has sold fast food snacks; she started this business  two years ago.  She’s asking for a loan to enlarge the locale to accommodate more clientele.  Her neighbors classify her as being a hard working person.

She is happy at the time of requesting the loan.  She is 54 years old and finished high school.  She’s married and has a son.  

She wants the loan to enlarge the locale and she also expects that her sales and income will increase.

Esther S. is the group President.  She’s 21 years old and finished middle school.  She’s married and has two children.  She has sold shoes for the last year.  She is asking for the loan to increase her credit at the shoe shop.

The group has 9 members and this is their first loan request.

loans.use: To enlarge the locale to sell Mexican food.

loans.name: Mario Alfonso

texts.es:
Mario T., está aplicando a su quinto credito con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo y a su  segundo credikiva porque se surtirá de útiles escolares  como libretas, lápices, colores, bolígrafos, cartulinas y bloques de papel carta y oficio; así mismo comprará repuestos como toma corriente, balineras, bovinas y aletas para abanicos, todo esto en términos  de satisfacer los pedidos de sus clientes, lo cual garantiza que su inversión sea exitosa. Su meta y gran desafío es tener una vivienda propia y en este propósito él y su esposa, quien aparece en la fotografía, se esfuerzan mucho  trabajando para lograr conseguirlo.
Si usted quiere conocer la historia de Mario ingrese al siguiente enlace:
http://kiva.org/lend/173600
texts.en:
Mario T. is applying for his fifth Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, second Kiva loan to stock up on school supplies like notebooks, pencils, crayons, ball point pens, construction paper and reams of letter and legal size paper as well as to buy parts like plugs, ball bearings, ignition coils and fan blades in order to fill customer orders thus guaranteeing a successful investment.

His goal and great challenge is to have his own house and this is his and his wife’s, who appears in the photo, purpose.  They exert much effort to work hard to attain it.

If you’d like to know Mario’s history, please click on the following link:

http://kiva.org/lend/173600

loans.use: To buy school supplies like notebooks, pencils, crayons, ball point pens, construction paper, reams of letter and legal size paper as well as electrical parts like plugs, ball bearings, ignition coils and blades for fans.

loans.name: Saret's Group

texts.en:
This group loan consists of six members who have selected Mrs. Saret to be the group leader. All the members will use their portion of the loan in varied ways to improve their family's standard of living. 

Mrs. Saret was born in 1963. She and her husband, Mr. Yung, are farmers who own a 2-hectare plot of land where they grow rice. They sell some part of the crop and the other part they use to support their family. 

Now it is the dry season, so it is time for growing crops. So to improve their production, Mrs. Saret would like to apply for a loan to do farming. She is a mother of six children, three of whom are seamstresses in garment factories, while the others are studying in the local public school.

loans.use: to do farming.

loans.name: Maria Evelyn

texts.en:
Maria Evelyn R. is from the village of Western Wao, Lanao del Sur. She is 48 years old. Maria Evelyn is a widow and has four adult-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling coffee, soaps, candies and snack foods in the local community. She also deals in selling AVON products. Maria Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $100 a month for these activities.

In 2011, Maria Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell like soaps, canned goods and beverages. This will be her 1st loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell like soaps, canned goods and beverages

loans.name: Abigail

texts.en:
Abigail M. is from the village of Barangay 24, Gingoog City. She is 47 years old. Abigail is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Abigail owns & operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling beverages including energy drinks & soft drinks in the local community. Abigail has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2011, Abigail joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Abigail is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional stock or cases of beverages. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Abigail from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional stock or cases of beverages.

location.town: Barangay 24, Magallanes, Gingoog City, Misamis Ori

loans.name: Ni Ketut

texts.en:
Ni Ketut K., 31, is married and has two children. She works as a farmer and earns an average income of Rp. 1,000,000 per month. She applied for a loan of Rp. 5,000,000 to buy fertilizer for cocoa, bananas and beans in her garden, so the plants will have more fruit. In addition to buying chemical fertilizer, she also uses organic fertilizer to maintain the natural preservation. 

Ni Ketut K. plans to save the benefits that will result from her farming for the future of her children. Ni Ketut K. lives with her husband and two children. Her children still attend school. Ni Ketut K. spends Rp. 30,000 for kitchen expenses every day. This is her first loan with MUK.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer.

loans.name: Ablavi

texts.fr: Mariée à un soudeur, Mme Ablavi a reçu une formation en menuiserie alumininium mais après son diplôme elle n’a pas eu la chance dans ce métier, pour se faire elle a opté pour une activité parallèle, celle de la vente des habits basins (tissus africains faits à la main par des femmes d’origine sahélienne). Elle  s’approvisionne au Mali et revend  à domicile à ses clientes. Elle a 02 enfants et aimerait aussi participer aux charges financière de la maison.et ce crédit lui permettra de se relancer dans la vie active.
texts.en: Married to a welder, Mrs. Ablavi has been trained as an aluminum furniture maker, but after receiving her diploma she has had no luck in that field. Therefore she chose a parallel activity, selling “bazins” outfits (African fabrics made by hand by women from the Sahel Region). She stocks up in Mali and resells to her clients out of her home. She has two children and would like to contribute to the family budget. This loan will  give a boost to her business activities.

loans.use: to buy traditional "bazins" fabrics

loans.name: Cleofe

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “MADRES TRABAJADORAS”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Cleofe; ella tiene 39 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 2 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de frutas, ella vende naranjas, manzanas, platanos, uvas y entre otras frutas, la socia vende en el mercado de Huancaro desde las 6:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m, por medio de este negocio la socia saca adelante a sus hijos, la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de venta de frutas.La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar frutas al por mayor. 

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Cleofe is a member of the 'Madres Trabajadoras' community bank which is located in Cusco district, in Cusco province and department.

Cleofe is 39 years old, lives with her partner, and has two children.  She divides her time between her daily activities and her fruit business.  She sells oranges, apples, bananas, grapes and other fruit.  Cleofe sells her produce in Huancaro market, from 6.00am to 6.00pm.  Through her business she gets her children ahead in life.  She would like to expand and improve her fruit business.  She is requesting this loan to buy fruit wholesale.

Cleofe is happy to be receiving the loan and pledges to make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to buy fruit wholesale

loans.name: Nemesio

texts.es: El señor Nemesio se dedica a prestar servicios de limpieza y conserjería en edificios es propietario de una empresa de limpieza que ya trabaja en nuestra ciudad  hace 4 años, presta servicios a oficinas y domicilios solicita el crédito para incrementar para la compra de un lote, el señor tiene 3 hijos menores uno está en la escuela, su esposa se dedica a la venta de comida en una acera del centro de la ciudad.  El señor es emprendedor por que pretende expandir su microempresa a la ciudad de La Paz debido a que presta excelentes servicios y sus clientes le recomendaron, su deseo es el de poder crecer en su negocio, es una persona responsable y trabajadora, esta muy agradecido con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Mr. Nemesio is in the cleaning and janitorial services business.  He owns a cleaning company that has been active in our city for four years, providing services to offices and private homes.  He is requesting a loan to buy bulk supplies.

He has three minor, school-aged children and his wife is a sidewalk food vendor in the city center.  Nemesio is an entrepreneur who wants to expand his small business in the city of La Paz.  He gives excellent service and is recommended by his customers.  He is very responsible and hard-working, and very grateful to the institution for the support he has received.

loans.use: To buy bulk supplies.

loans.name: John B

texts.en:
This is 41-year-old John.  He is married and has two children aged two and five. He has two additional dependents, who live with him because they are his nieces.  In 2009, John established his electrical spare parts business. He began his business because he had gained experience from his elder brother and wanted to be self-employed and be able to provide livelihood for his family. 

Working six days a week and 10 hours a day, he earns about Le 700,000 every month from this business. He would like a loan in the amount of Le 4,500,000. John requires a loan in order to buy additional electrical spare parts. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately Le 300,000. In the future, John plans to develop his plot of land and to educate his children.   He thanks you for your support

loans.use: To pay for electrical spare parts.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa de 45 años de edad, reside con su hija Reyna de 24 años en su casa. Rosa es muy trabajadora y responsable. Ha trabajado toda su vida para sacar adelante a su querida hija que ya es mayor de edad, quien ahora también ayuda con el negocio. Rosa se dedica a la venta de verduras frescas en la zona donde habita. Es una mujer ejemplar ya que a pesar de su edad no se da por vencida, a tempranas horas de la mañana se levanta para tener lista las verduras que sus clientes demandan con frecuencia. Su sueño es contar con mayor variedad de verduras frescas para ofrecer a sus clientes y tener suficientes a la hora que le demanden. Para esto necesita este crédito que solicita a INTEGRAL para poder comprar mayores cantidades de las diferentes verduras como: tomates, papas, zanahorias, chiles, güisquiles, limones, etc. Que le permitan mejorar sus ventas así como su nivel de ingresos, con el objetivo de mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en: Rosa is 45 years old and lives in a house with her daughter Reyna, age 24. Rosa is very hard-working and responsible. She has worked all her life to help her beloved daughter get ahead. Her daughter is now an adult and also helps her with the business. Rosa works selling fresh vegetables in the area where she lives. She is an exemplary woman, since in spite of her age, she is not slowing down. She gets up early in the morning to get the vegetables ready that her customers most often request. Her dream is to have a greater variety of fresh vegetables to offer to her customers, and to have a large enough supply available when her buyers want them. Because of this, she needs the loan she is requesting from INTEGRAL to buy larger quantities of various vegetables such as tomatoes, potatoes, carrots, chilies, chayotes, limes, etc. This will allow her to improve her sales and raise her income level, with the aim of improving her quality of life.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, potatoes, carrots, chilies, chayotes, limes, etc.

loans.name: Adriana Katiny

texts.es:
Adriana Katiny tiene 19 años, Es casada vive con el esposo y con un hijos, en el Cantón Ventanas Provincia de los Ríos. 

Los miembros de la V.R.C. NUEVO AMANECER, se encuentra ubicada en el Recinto San Luis de Zapotal, perteneciente al Cantón Ventanas, esta ventanilla son 12 miembros se en su mayoría dedica a labores como siembre de maíz y arroz, actividad mas antigua.


Adriana Katiny se dedica a la agricultura a la siembra de maíz y arroz. Compra sus productos en Comercial PRONACA y los vende en el mercado mayorista de Ventanas.

Solicita el crédito para sembrar maíz y arroz,  compra de semilla, abonos y remedios para los cultivos.   Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentan desafíos como enfermedades de los trabajadores y falta de dinero para seguir invirtiendo. Su sueño es comprar mas tierras para seguir sembrando.

Le gusta cantar, jugar pelota y caminar por los cultivos.
texts.en:
Adriana Katiny is 19 years old, married, and lives with her husband and children in the canton of Ventanas in Los Ríos Province.

The members of the Communal Bank “Nuevo Amanecer” (New Dawn) meet in the neighborhood of Recinto San Luis de Zapotal, which is part of the canton of Ventanas. This Communal Bank has 12 members, most of whom are long-time farmers who grow corn and rice.

Adriana Katiny is a farmer who grows corn and rice. She buys her products at the PRONACA Commercial Center and sells at the wholesale market in Ventanas.

She is requesting a loan for growing corn and rice. Adriana will buy seeds, compost, and remedies for her crops. With the financial assistance provided through this loan, she will be able to acquire needed supplies. Some of the challenges she faces include diseases that could make her workers sick and the lack of money for making continued investments. Her dream is to buy more land so that she can continue planting.

Adriana enjoys singing, playing ball, and walking through her fields.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, compost, and remedies.

loans.name: Najma's Group

texts.en:
Najma is married and her husband works in a grocery store for a low income. His income is not enough for the whole family, that's why Najma started doing business a few years ago to financially support her family. She purchases used warm clothes, gets thread out of them, and then sells it to the thread sellers of the market, earning a good profit. 

She is the mother of five sons. Najma couldn't educate them due to financial constraints. Three of them also work in a grocery store while the other two stay at home. 

Najma has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for the further expansion of her thread-selling business. With the loan, she will buy sweaters in larger quantities that will allow her to get more thread for selling. 

She has been doing this business for the past 14 years. She is confident that an investment will help her make more profits and make her family's life easier. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her second loan application. In a previous loan year, she has established good credit behavior and never missed any meetings. 

Note: In the photo, the lady raising her hand is Najma.

loans.use: To buy used warm clothes (sweaters) to recycle into thread

loans.name: Annie

texts.en:
Annie is 41 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 4 children. Annie has a retail shop that sells canned goods, snacks, noodles and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. 

She requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, beverages and snacks. She is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Annie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, beverages and snacks.

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
40-year-old Emily is a married woman with 4 children. The oldest child is 17 years old, while the youngest is 5.

Emily is a farmer who tills land in Banga, in the province of South Cotabato. She primarily grows rice to sell to the people in her community. Aside from farming, she also runs a sari-sari (convenience) store. She sells items such as noodles, canned goods, and soap.

Emily has requested a loan to purchase fertilizer and more items to sell at the store. She hopes to have a successful business in the future. She also hopes for her children to finish college and have bright futures.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and more items to sell at her sari-sari store

loans.name: Eva Maria

texts.es:
Eva de 40 años de edad, vive con su esposo e hijos en su casa propia, cuenta con servicio de luz solamente, ubicada en la zona rural del distrito de Tambogrande que pertenece al departamento de Piura.  Zona que se caracteriza por la actividad agrícola, ganadera y artesanía.

Eva ha colocado un bazar donde ofrece todo tipo de productos para el uso personal y visutería, desde hace algunos año, su negocio lo tiene en su domicilio, lo que le permite atender a sus clientes en ctratando de tener mayor demanda de clientes y así pueda obtener más ingresos para solventar sus gastos personales.

Al observar que su negocio cada día es más próspero a creído necesario solicitar un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1000 nuevos soles para implementar comprando mercadería innovadora para que tenga acogida con sus clientes, con la finalidad que su clientela siga aumentando en su bazar para poder pagar su crédito y mejorar su calidad de vida, para seguir apoyando económicamente a sus hijos.
texts.en:
40-year-old Eva lives with her husband and children in her own home which only has electricity.  Her home is located in the rural part of Tambogrande district, in Piura department.  This area is noted for its farming, livestock raising and handicrafts.

Eva has set up a store where she sells all kinds of personal care products and costume jewelry.  She has been in this business for several years and her store is located in her home which allows her to serve her customers in comfort.  She tries to attract more customers so that she can make more income with which to cover her personal expenses.

Noting that her business was doing better and better each day, Eva decided it was necessary to request a loan for 1,000 soles from Edpyme Alternativa in order to stock her business, buying new merchandise to please her customers.  Her goal is to continue increasing her number of customers so that she can repay her loan, improve her quality of life and continue financially supporting her children.

loans.use: to buy new merchandise with which to stock her business

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
This is Lydia, 55, a resident of Bacoor, CaviteCity, Philippines. She is married to Jovencio, a construction worker, and has children. She manages her household while operating her own business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Lydia operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them retail. Aside from this she also retails charcoal. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 350 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

She is requesting a Php15,000 loan which she will use to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. Lydia dreams of giving her children a good and high quality education by working hard at her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, and she also draws strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. * All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery and other inventory for her store.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is from the village of Sillawit. She is 54 years old, married and has one child. To make a living, Erlinda owns and operates her general store. She has been engaged in her business for many years.

Now, Erlinda is requesting a loan of PHP 7,000 to purchase additional stock such as canned goods, biscuits, coffee, milk, and sugar to sell in their village. She hopes to expand her business with the help of this loan.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, biscuits, coffee, milk, and sugar

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.

loans.name: Maria

texts.es: María tiene 34 años, es una mujer alegre y muy dinámica, le gusta mucho trabajar y encuentra en todo lo que hace una manera de ganarse la vida. Ella esta casada y tiene seis hijos. Juntos habitan en su casa que es propia, en donde comparten la armonia y buenas costumbres. El trabajo de María consiste en la venta de golosonas, actividad que lo hace de manera ambulante. Es así que diariamente se establece en las afueras de los colegios, que es ahí sus pequeños clientes la buscan para comprar algún producto.
