A typical huipil requires a $30 investment and can be sold for about $100-$200, depending on the design and time required to make it. They also weave skirts, belts, and blankets that they sell to neighbors who place orders, or in the markets of the closest cities.

They will pay their loan back over the next year, and are eager to begin saving for their children’s education, which they say is the most important thing to them, and the reason they work as hard as they do.

loans.use: To purchase thread for weaving

loans.name: Melissa Del Carmen

texts.es:
Mrs. S. G. lives in the Residencial Bosques de Juigalpan, house # R-22, where she lives together with her family, which is compose of her husband and two school-aged children, one in the fifth grade of primary school and the other, eight years old and in the third grade. Through her own effort she has been able to establish a beauty salon in her home, which allows her to provide services to local customers and provide home service including hairstyling, cuts, manicures and decorations for hands and feet. This provides her with an income to guarantee the wellbeing of her family and consolidate her small business. Because her clientele demands it, she is available twenty-four hours. Her husband works as a customer assistant in a supermarket and helps sustain the household. She is requesting a loan of $1,100.00 to buy an chair for her beauty salon that would help with haircuts for both men and women; this would improve her income and the conditions of her family life.

Translated from Spanish by Sheila Johnson, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. S. G. habita en el Residencial Bosques de Juigalpan, casa # R-22, donde habita junto a su familia compuesta por su marido y 2 hijos en edad escolar, 10 años en 5to grado de primaria y el otro en 3er grado, de 8 años de edad; por esfuerzo propio ha logrado establecer un salon de belleza en su casa de habitacion, lo que le permite brindar servicio a clientes locales y brinda servicio a domicilio realizando peinados, cortes, manicure y decoraciones de mano y pies, lo que le brinda ingresos para garantizar el bienestar familiar y consolidar su pequeño negocio; está disponible las 24 horas, ya que su clientela asi lo demanda; el marido labora como despachador en supermercado y apoya a la sotenibilidad del hogar, solicita credito por C$.20,000.00 para adquirir una silla adecuada para su salon de belleza. Y así poder mejorar la atención a sus clientes y por ende los ingresos familiares

loans.use: Purchase of equipment for her busines

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en:
Christiana A., 38, is married with 3 children who are currently schooling. She is a food vendor and sells fufu. Fufu is prepared from cassava and plantain, cooked and pounded together and eaten with different kinds of soup. It is a very popular traditional food among the Ashanti tribe of Ghanaian society. It is enjoyed as breakfast, lunch, and/or supper.

Christiana wants to use this loan to buy more raw materials such as plantains, cassava, meat, fish, vegetables, and also firewood. She hopes to increase her income to support her children’s education. She belongs to the community group called Twen Awurade (Wait upon the Lord) Trust Group. In this group, members guarantee for one another as social collateral to access a loan and peer pressure to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials for food preparation: plantains, cassava, meat, fish, vegetables, and also firewood

loans.name: Lucia Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita is 42 years old and she currently works as an administrator in a business in the city of Managua. She lives in the neighbourhood Laureles Sur and she is married with 2 kids who are 13 and 16. They are studying in secondary school thanks to their parents' hard work, and her husband helps out with the family's expenses.

With the loan that she is asking for she will replace the roof of their house which is currently in a really bad state, and because of the heavy rains they have a lot of leaks. She hopes to do up her house little by little to give her family the best living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

Doña Margarita tiene 42 años de edad y actualmente se desempeña como administradora de una empresa de laciudad de Managua, habita en el barrio Laureles Sur, es casada, y tiene dos hijos de 13 y 16 años de edad, quines al gran esfuerzo que hacen sus padres están estudiando la educación secundaria, su esposo la apoya con los gastos familiares. Con el préstamo que está solicitando cambiará el techo de su casa que actualmente se encuentra en muy mal estado, y debido a las lluvias están sufriendo filtraciones de agua. Espera poco a poco poder componer su casa de habitación para darles las mejores condiciones de vida a su familia.

loans.use: To change the roof of their house/Cambiar el techo de su casa

loans.name: Griselda Del Carmen

texts.en:
Griselda operates a business selling used American clothing and is requesting this loan to buy more clothes to sell. She started a business selling gold six years ago. Over time, the business grew and has generated good income, so she wanted more capital to continue negotiating and investing more because she used the income that this generated for basic items for her family.

A friend told her that FAPE helps women micro-entrepreneurs to advance in their businesses and she joined one of FAPE's trust banks, called Alpha and Omega, through which she received a loan that she says helped her a lot. A year ago she opened her American clothing store, which has helped her a lot and sales are good. Right now she has the opportunity to buy very high quality American clothing in bulk, but doesn't currently have the money for it so that is why she is requesting this loan. Griselda is 31 years old and was born in Jocotan Chiquimula, but actually lives in Villa Nueva, near the capital city of Guatemala. Translated from Spanish by Megan Montgomery, Kiva Fellow. Griselda tiene una venta de ropa americana usada y está pidiendo este préstamo para comprar más ropa para vender. Ella inició un negocio vendiendo oro hace 6 años. Con el paso del tiempo, el negocio fue creciendo y ha generado buenas ganancias por lo cual necesitaba capital para seguir negociando e invertir más porque las ganancias que ya generaba las estaban utilizando para cosas de consumo familiar. Una amiga le contó que FAPE ayudaba a las mujeres microempresarias a salir adelante con sus negocios y le integró en un banco de confianza denominado alfa y omega, con el cual adquirió un crédito que dice que le ayudó mucho. Hace un año abrió su venta de ropa americana en la cual le ayudó bastante y vende muy bien. Ahorita ella tiene la oportunidad de comprar una paca (ropa americana a granel) de muy buena calidad, pero no cuenta con el capital para comprarlo y por eso está pidiendo este préstamo individual. Griselda tiene 31 años y nació en Jocotan Chiquimula, pero actualmente vive en Villa Nueva, cerca de la ciudad capital de Guatemala.

loans.use: To buy more used clothing to sell in her business (comprar ropa usada para vender en su negocio)

loans.name: Audely Georgina

texts.es:
Audely decided five years ago to open a convenience store in her home. The investment was small since she had very little capital. She began selling basic grains, sweets and cooked beans. With time her business has grown and she has been able to diversify the products on offer. The loan will be used to buy beauty products as an investment in her business. Audely lives in the San Judas neighborhood. She is single and all of her children are grown. With a lot of effort she was able to give each of them an education so that they would be productive and successful members of society.

Translated from Spanish by Erin Corcoran, Kiva volunteer.

Doña Audely hace 5 años decidió poner una pulpería en su casa de habitación, la inversión fue poca ya que contaba con poco capital para iniciar, puso e la venta granos básicos, golosinas y frijoles cocidos, con el tiempo su negocio ha ido creciendo y ha podido diversificar su producto. El uso del crédito será para comprar productos de belleza para invertir en su negocio. Doña Audely habita en el barrio San Judas es soltera y todos sus hijos ya son mayores de edad, con mucho esfuerzo les pudo dar educación para que éstos fueran personas de bien para la sociedad.

loans.use: Purchase of an inventory of  beauty products as an investment in her convenience store.

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi L. is 30 years old. In 2002 she joined TYM Fund and borrowed a loan for pig raising. At present, she is responsible for this business and her husband drives a small truck to transport goods for other people. For 6 years in TYM she has complied with TYM's regulations and repaid loans in a timely fashion. For the coming loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 6 million to buy a cow to raise for sale.

loans.use: buy a cow to raise for sale

loans.name: Res

texts.en:
Res M., age 49, is a widowed fish seller who lives with two of her five children in Phnom Penh, Cambodia. She typically makes $10 each day and is aided by her daughter, who works in a garment factory. 

Res M. is asking for a loan of $400 to purchase a motorbike, a purchase that she sees as a good opportunity to increase her income.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike

loans.name: Rosa

texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the Paloma (“Dove”) Village Bank. She is 57 years old and married with five children. She has a small store in her house (near the stadium in the city of Ayacucho) where she sells dry goods, vegetables, meat, fish and drinks. She works 7 days a week from 6am to 11pm. Rosa needs a loan of 1000 soles to buy sugar, rice, beer and soda. Rosa dreams of totally outfitting her business and leaving a business to each one of her children.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva fellow

Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal Paloma. Rosa es casada, tiene 57 años y 5 hijos, Rosa tiene una bodega en su casa que se ubica cerca al estadio de la ciudad de Ayacucho, en donde vende abarrotes, verduras, carne, pescado, bebidas, actividad que realiza todos los dias de la semana, desde las 6 de la mañana hasta las 11 de la noche. Rosa necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar, arroz, cerveza, gaseosa. Rosa sueña con implementar su negocio, dejar negocios para cada uno de sus hijos.

loans.use: Rosa would like to buy rice, sugar, beer and soda to sell.

loans.name: Jose

texts.en:
Jose D. became a widower during the early stage of his marriage.  Since then, he has been the father and mother of his three daughters: Lean – 17 years old, a high school graduate; Shella – 16 years old, fourth year high school student and Melvin Joy – 14 years old, a second year high school student.  

Jose is very assiduous in his farming business.  But due to lack of money, he could not sustain all his farming needs.  He really needs to continue his farming business because it is the only means for him to send his children to school and for his eldest child to pursue her college education.  He requests a loan of PHP 18,000 to purchase farm inputs like fertilizers and seeds.  He is really thankful to God that there people who are willing to lend him without asking for high interest compared to the traders.

He is proud that despite being a single parent, he still manages to send his children to school.  He is able to do this because he manages the farm and hog raising businesses well.

Jose is a man with a word of honor.  He does not promise anything that he is not sure of.  He said that he will sacrifice everything to provide a better life for her children, so he has to work hard and pray for his success.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs like fertilizers and seeds

loans.name: Sokkhoeun

texts.en:
Mrs. Sokkhoeun T., 33, and her husband, Mr. Senghout Chea, 37, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1991 and have one daughter who attends school. The daughter assists her with weaving silk when she is free from her studies. Sokkhoeun also has her grandmother living with her.

Sokkhoeun has been a silk weaver for 19 years, a skill she learned from her grandmother. She sells her finished product to a middleman, who then takes it to re sell at the market in Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. Sokkhoeun has also been hired by the villagers to spin silk where she can earn extra income. Her husband has been a mechanic in Phnom Penh for a year.

Sokkhoeun is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase silk material for weaving and to buy a motorbike for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for weaving and a motorbike.

loans.name: Carmen

texts.es:
A pesar de ser una mujer muy joven, Carmen ha hecho mucho en su vida con el fin de progresar. Durante tres años ella trabajo ofreciendo el servicio de limpieza en un club de recreación cerca de su casa. Luego de haber ahorrado lo suficiente para alquilar un local y abrir su propio negocio, abandonó su trabajo en el club y se dedicó a la implementación y servicio de su propio bar.

Aunque no le fue mal en este negocio al poco tiempo también tuvo que dejarlo, pues no tenía quien se hiciera cargo de sus dos pequeños hijos, uno de ellos recién nacido en aquel entonces. Por lo que no tuvo otra opción más que trabajar en su casa.

Hoy en día y desde hace cinco años vende gaseosas y cervezas por las tardes. Desde este año también vende ropa a domicilio y por las mañanas apoya en el comedor popular que el estado mantiene. Dentro de sus planes esta el construir su casa con material de concreto para poder surtir su tienda con muchos más productos.
texts.en:
In spite of being a very young woman, Carmen has done a lot in her life to make a progress in life. She worked at a cleaning service company for three years at a recreation center nearby her home. After saving enough money to rent her own place, she decided to open her own business. She quit her job at the center and stated to work on her new bar. Even though the business was doing well, she had to close it after a while, as she didn’t have anybody to take care of her small children, one of then a new borne back then. She didn’t have any other choice but to start working from home. Today, and for the last five years, she’s been selling sodas and beer in the afternoon. Starting this year, she diversified her business starting selling clothes. In the mornings, she helps at a community dinner supported by the government. Her plans include building her house out of concrete and to diversify her business even further.

Translated from Spanish by Jimena Lopez, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothes to sell

loans.name: Wilmer

texts.es:
Desde que tenia veinte años se dedica al rubro de la carpintería. Hoy a sus veintinueve años es dueño de un taller de carpintería que este año cumple cinco años desde que se inicio.
Wilmer de muy joven ha trabajado como comerciante vendiendo diversos productos como lanas y jabones. No fue sino después de haber abandono su trabajo en una fábrica de cerrajería que ingreso a trabajar en un depósito de madera, donde el interés por la carpintería nació.
Su sueño siempre fue tener un negocio propio, poco a poco durante los años que han pasado ha sabido administrar bien su taller y hoy goza de buena clientela. A la par con su trabajo, actualmente esta estudiando diseño de interiores para en un par de años tener tiendas de muebles.
Compra de materiales para su taller
texts.en:
Wilmer C. A. has worked in carpentry since he was twenty years old. Now, at the age of twenty-nine, he is the owner of a carpentry shop that he opened almost five years ago. Since a very young age, Wilmer has worked as a tradesman, selling a variety of products such as cloth and soaps. It was not until after he left his job at a locksmith factory that he began to work at a lumberyard, and it was there that his interest in carpentry was born. He had always dreamed of owning his own business. Little by little over the years, he has learned how to be a good business manager. Today, he enjoys a strong clientele. On top of this job, he is currently studying interior design so that in a couple of years he can open a furniture shop. He requests this loan to purchase materials for his carpentry shop.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase materials for his carpentry shop

loans.name: Elizabeth Atieno

texts.en:
Elizabeth Atieno A. is a 48-year-old mother of six children; some are in college but the others are still waiting to go. She sells second-hand clothes in Manyatta slum, where she also lives. Her main challenge, she says, is a lack of money, and she will use this loan to pay for more clothes. She will use the profits to pay for school fees for her children.

Elizabeth recently joined the K-MET volunteer Community Health Worker (CHW) group in Kisumu, Kenya. As a CHW she will be trained by K-MET and will begin visiting members of her community who are sick with a variety of illness. Her work will include distributing Nutriflour (a vitamin enriched flour produced by K-MET) to malnourished patients, providing reproductive health education, referring patients to local clinics and hospitals, and providing basic health care.

loans.use: To purchase more clothing stock

loans.name: Amor Y Esperanza 1 & 2 Group

texts.en:
The Amor y Esperanza (Love and Hope) Bank of Hope group is ready to start its entrepreneurial endeavor with Esperanza International. The members of this group are very excited about receiving their loans and bringing new life to their businesses. They feel very thankful to be given the opportunity to receive a loan and improve their lives through their own work. 

Yolanda P. V. is the group coordinator. She has four children who are all grown up (the youngest is 26 years old). However, they all still live with her and she supports them financially. Her business consists of selling clothing from her house. She purchases clothes in bundles, then sells the clothes, and this activity is what her first loan will be used for. If sales are good, she can sell them all in a month. This bundle will be entirely of children’s clothing, not necessarily because it sells better, but, in Yolanda’s words, “Because these are the clothes I like to sell.” She thinks the fact that she dedicates her business to only the clothes she likes to sell will make her business progress.  She hopes in the future to buy and sell bundles with bedding (sheets and towels) as well as clothes for adults. 

Matelo C. is the group two coordinator. He has six children who are all living with him. He sells vegetables in a stand at a local market. He buys his vegetables from a large supplier in the same market and sells them in his small stand.  The vegetables he sells the most are carrots and eggplant. Eggplant is a popular food in Dominican Republic because it doesn’t cost much, making it affordable when meat is too expensive.  Also, it serves as a good siD. dish with rice and beans, which is the traditional Dominican meal. Matelo thinks it’s important for a stand in a market to look attractive so that customers are drawn to it. He also thinks a seller must be aware of his customers’ demands because demands vary from person to person. He hopes this first loan with Esperanza International will help him increase his sales and help him set up a larger stand in the market.

Please help these new micro entrepreneurs launch their initiatives to generate income and improve their quality of life. On behalf of Esperanza International, thank you for your support!

loans.use: Buy bundles of clothing to restock her inventory

loans.name: Maria Jesusa

texts.es:
La señora María es socia del Banco Comunal “Mujeres trabajando por el desarrollo“, en la comunidad Kocani Joven, el distrito de Cabanilla, de la provincia de Lampa, departamento de Puno, ella tiene 46 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene 06 hijos, ella pose estudios de primaria incompleta (quinto grado). 

Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos hace 04 años, es una de las socias fundadoras; actualmente ella se dedica al engorde ganado ovino, su primer préstamo fue de S/ 300.00 nuevos soles, monto que le sirvió para comprar más ganado (ovejas) para engorde. 

Actualmente ella desea un préstamo adicional de S/ 1500.00 nuevos soles, el mismo que se comprometa pagar en 06 cuotas. Con dicho préstamo ella desea adquirir ganado dos vacunos (un toro y una vaca) para engordarlos y venderlos en las ferias ganaderas de Cabanillas; su deseo es conseguir vacas lecheras y producir quesos para los grandes mercados.
texts.en:
Maria is a member of the "Women working towards development" communal bank, in the community of Kocani Joven, which lies in Cabanilla district, in Lampa province, in the Puno region. She is 46 years old and is a single mother to six children. She has a fifth grade education. Maria has worked with the Manuela Ramos movement (a Peruvian feminist nonprofit organization) for four years. She is one of the founding loan members; currently she works at fattening sheep for sale. Her first loan was for 300 soles, which she used to purchase more sheep (ewes) to fatten. Currently she desires an additional loan of 1500 soles, which she will repay in 6 installments. With this loan, she would purchase two more sheep (one ram and one ewe) to fatten them up and sell them at the livestock fairs of Cabanillas. Maria's ambition is to obtain milk cows and produce cheese for the large markets.

Translated from Spanish by Leah Karlins, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sheep

loans.name: Sakina Bashir Ahmad Group

texts.en:
Sakina baji is a wife of B. A. and has lived in Riwind, Pakistan for the past 10 years. Riwind is a mid-size city famous for its sweetmeats and shrines. Her husband deals in utensils, which he buys from the famous bazaars (Shahalmi and Ichra) of the city Lahore and sells to the utensil shops. He has 5 years of experience in this business.

Sakina baji is the mother of five kids: four sons and one daughter. Her first two sons work in a factory for a monthly wage. The others are enrolled in a school and are getting education. Sakina baji successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying again for a loan to buy utensils to expand her husband’s business.

She is the group leader of four other women from her locality. Bushra baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo for a milk business. Naziran baji wants a loan to buy scrap for a scrap business. Shamim akhtar baji wants a loan to buy snacks (chips, biscuits) to sell. Sakina baji wants a loan to buy cooking oil to sell.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy utensils to sell

loans.name: Savat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Savat K. is the group leader for four members who all live in the Dei Edth Kaoh Phos village in the province of Kandal.

She is a vendor of Chinese noodle soup. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand it. This is why she has decided to ask for a loan, specifically to purchase more beef, pork, and the other ingredients required for making the delicious soup she sells to her customers. She hopes to increase her income and her customer base.

Mrs. Savat K. is 51 years old and is a widow with three children. One of her children is a coffee seller and the others are employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase beef, pork, and other ingredients for soup

loans.name: Tausi

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is 26-year-old Tausi G. from Mwanza. She is married with one child who is 6 years old. Additionally, she is responsible for supporting one dependant who is an orphan. Tausi has been running a clothing business since 2007. Her business is selling clothes to the customers. She works at the business for 12 hours per day, 6 days per week and is assisted by one employee. Tausi currently earns about 150USD from her business. She is requesting a loan of 400USD in order to purchase more clothes and to increase her capital. In the future, she plans to open another business. Tausi thanks you for her support!

ABOUT SELFINA
SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and to increase her capital.

loans.name: Victor Enrique

texts.es:
En la ciudad de Managua, capital del bello país de Nicaragua, el señor Victor R. se dedica arduamente a trabajar en su negocio de venta de pollo en piezas y venta de embutidos los cuales son a diario vendidos en su establecimiento donde es visitado por los clientes.

Con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado salir adelante y hoy en día ha llegado a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de 700 libras de pollo para continuar ofertándolas porque actualmente se le están agotando y requiere invertir en dichas compras para mejorar su condición actual.
texts.en:
Victor R. works arduously at his business in Managua, the capital of the beautiful country of Nicaragua. He sells chicken pieces and sausages. His customers come to his establishment every day to buy his products. He has been able to get ahead through much effort. He is now asking Ceprodel for a loan to buy 700 pounds of chicken to continue selling them. He is running out of chicken, so he needs to buy more to allow him to improve his current condition.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy chicken and sausages

loans.name: Benkadi 4 De Toura Nabitokan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe BENKADI 4 est composé de femmes mariées du village de Toura Nabitokan de la ville de SAN région de SEGOU (quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali) qui vivent dans des familles traditionnelles. Elles ont en moyenne 47 ans, au moins 4 enfants et  cultivent  de l’arachide. 
Dans le souci de rentabiliser leurs exploitations agricoles, les membres du groupe Benkadi 4 de Toura  Nabitokan ont décidé d’intégrer le programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 2 ans. Après avoir correctement remboursé  le  prêt précédent, elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne.
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter, une quantité suffisante de semence d’arachide, des petits matériels et des intrants pour la culture, exclusivement  au grand marché de Kimparana  ville. Après l’hivernage, les récoltes sont stockées pendant un certain  temps pour qu’elles aient de la valeur avant d’être vendues  au grand marché de Kimparana et  dans les  marchés  environnants, en détail (souvent en gros), au comptant  à une clientèle venant généralement des grandes villes.
Les membres du groupe BENKADI 4 de Toura Nabitokan comptent réaliser chacune, après l’écoulement de leurs produits agricoles, un bénéfice de 30 000 à 20 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé  pour le remboursement des intérêts du prêt  et les dépenses courantes de la famille.
texts.en:
The BENKADI 4 group is made of married women of the Toura Nabitokan village, in the city of SAN (Ségou Region, fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali), who live in traditional families. They average 47 years of age, and have at least 4 children. They grow peanuts.

Eager to make their agricultural businesses profitable, the members of the BENKADI 4 group decided to join the loan program of Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, two years ago. After having repaid the previous loan without problems, they are now seeking their second farming loan.

This loan will be used to buy, exclusively at the grand market in Kimparana, a sufficient quantity of peanut seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields. After the rainy season, the crops are stored for a while to gain market value, before being sold at the grand market in Kimparara and in the surrounding markets, retail (often wholesale) and for cash, to a clientele usually coming from the larger cities.

After selling their products, the members of the BENKADI 4 group count on turning a profit of XOF 30000 to 20000 (ca US$ 65 to 45) each, to be used to repay the loan and to pay for the daily expenses of their families.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds, small materials, and fertilizers for the fields

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
Lucia A. is currently in the business of selling beer in a bar and is requesting a loan to stock more beer to sell. Lucia is 42 years old and married to a husband who is a businessman. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a little store for selling foodstuffs.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The micro-finance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more beer to sell

loans.name: Hector Ruben

texts.es: Héctor Rubén B. tiene 30 años de edad.  Su actividad económica que es la venta y compra de electrodomésticos. Hace más de 12 años que se dedica a este negocio. El dio inicio a este negocio porque le gustaba reparar   aparatos eléctricos y también vender este tipo de aparatos que son necesarios en el hogar y además tiene una hija que necesita de estudio y vestimenta por lo que esto lo motivo a salir adelante con este negocio. Su mayor desafío fue que algunas veces no conocía las direcciones de los clientes y esto le ocasionaba la pérdida de  mucho tiempo ya que tenía que buscar la dirección exacta. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de video juegos, licuadora, equipos de sonido televisores y algunos repuestos de electrodomésticos. El sueño de Héctor es terminar de construir su vivienda y brindarle a su familia las mejores condiciones.
texts.en:
Hector Ruben B. is 30 years old. He buys and sells household appliances. He has dedicated himself to this business for over 12 years. He began this business because he enjoyed repairing electronic appliances, and also selling these types of appliances that are necessary in the home. In addition, he has a daughter that needs clothing and to further her studies, which is the reason that he wants to move forward with this business. His biggest obstacle has been that at times he didn’t know his clients’ addresses, which caused him to waste a lot of time given that he has to look for the exact address. The loan that he is requesting will be used as work capital to purchase video games, a blender, sound equipment, televisions, and some spare parts for home appliances. Hector’s dream is to finish building his house, and to provide his family with the best living conditions.

Translated from Spanish by Mariela Cedeno, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Work capital (to purchase video games, a blender, sound equipment, televisions, and some spare parts for home appliances).

loans.name: Roberto

texts.es:
Roberto tiene 29 años, vive con su pareja y madre de su hijo y desde hace poco tiempo ya tienen una casa propia. Desde muy joven se ha dedicado al cultivo de plátanos y frutas cítricas como las naranjas y guanábanas, ya que estos frutos le permiten mantener a su familia. Por ello, desde muy temprano acude a sus chacras para abonarlas, limpiarlas y podarlas. Los plátanos los cosecha semanalmente y los vende por arrobas (12 kilos) entre 6 a 7 soles desde su misma chacra,  evitándose pagar el traslado al mercado. En el caso de los cítricos, la mayor inversión es el fumigado contra los mosquitos, en este caso, en los meses de enero a marzo los envía a un mercado de la ciudad de Lima donde le cotizan a un buen precio y eso le causa mucha alegría. Por ello está planeando comprar otras tierras donde pueda incrementar sus cultivos. 
Este es su segundo crédito con MFP, es por ello que renueva su compromiso de pagar puntualmente todas sus cuotas y de ese modo no perjudicar a su banco comunal. Con el dinero que solicita comprará abono para sus cultivos de plátano y los cítricos.

loans.use: Compra de abono

loans.name: Romela

texts.en:
Romela is a woman with something to prove - to her parents and to others who believed that she would account to nothing because she married very young and had no bankable working skills. Romela is now 34 years old and lives in the village of Purok Camansi, Brgy. Mailum, Bago City, Negros Occidental with her husband who works as a security guard, and their three children.  The oldest is now 17 years old and is studying aeronautics, the second is 16 years old, and is in the fourth year of high school, and the youngest is 11 and is still in elementary school.

When Romela married and got pregnant while still a teenager, her parents were disappointed because they thought all their dreams and aspirations for her would come to naught.  They were worried about how she would survive in the future. Acquaintances and relatives thought that she was throwing her life away. She proved all of them wrong by sheer will, determination and tirelessly working hard along with her husband to make a life for their young family.

While she was pregnant with her first child, her parents decided to close their business of buying and selling firewood and bamboo poles. Seeing an opportunity to help her husband by earning her own living, Romela decided to take over the business operations that her parents were closing up. With only the small amount of capital that her husband could provide, she was able to continue dealing with the same suppliers.  She earned the loyalty of the same customers because they did not have to go somewhere else. By planning her cash flow well, she was able to maintain the business and slowly make it into a stable source of income.

After several years, Romela saw that she needed to earn more if she was to provide her children with a better future. Her problem was where to find the necessary additional capital so that she could expand her business. When someone told her about NWTF-Project Dungganon, she immediately asked her husband's permission to join so that she could access the much-needed additional capital to increase her stocks of firewood and bamboo poles through loans that she could pay in weekly installments. 

Her business grew and she was able to increase her income, allowing her to afford her children's education and save for their future. She used her 3rd cycle loan to purchase a tricycle - a motorcycle with a side car - which she uses in her business, allowing her to make deliveries of the firewood and bamboo poles to her regular customers, increasing her income potential even further.

In the five years since she became an NWTF-Project Dungganon member, her business continues to improve and it earns approximately $225 a month for her family. Her previous loan - the 19th cycle loan amounting Php 10,000 - was used as additional capital for the business and it was fully paid on time without any delays.  For her 20th cycle loan she proposes to get the same amount of Php 10,000 as additional capital for her business. Her future plan is to expand her business and put up a general store.

About NWTF: 
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional capital

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
After many years as a stay-at-home mom, Nancy realized that she wanted her own career once her children were grown. Initially she wanted to go into traditional medicine and become a doctor, but she ultimately found alternative medicine more appealing.
 
Nancy began her holistic medicine and acupuncture business five years ago. Just after starting her business she and her husband divorced and went through bankruptcy. This made it pretty much impossible for her to receive a loan from a traditional bank. However, she found a new sense of confidence after realizing that she has a viable business and would in fact be eligible for a micro-loan from Opportunity Fund.
 
Nancy needs $8,000 to buy pre-packed supplements and to buy an alkaline water system. In the future, she hopes to expand her business to include workshops for other midlife women who are trying to find a new career in life or possibly start their own businesses. She feels that no one should “let life’s circumstances prevent them from doing what they want”.

loans.use: To buy pre-packed supplements and an alkaline water system

loans.name: Ige

texts.en: Ige is 35 years old and married with two children.  She lives in Oyo State, Nigeria and sells groundnut oil and foodstuffs.  Ige has been in business for the past 12 years. She requests a loan of N100,000 to purchase more groundnut oil and foodstuffs to sell.  She says thanks to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Purchase more groundnut oil and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is fifty-eight years old. She is divorced and has given birth to four children. All of her children are still in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in Kade. Kade is a farming/commercial town in the Eastern Region of Ghana. Comfort is a trader. She trades in pastries. She fries the pastries by the roadside in her community and supplies to retailers. Comfort has been in business for over nine years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase flour, oil, and other ingredients

loans.name: Rosenda

texts.en:
Rosenda T. is from the village of San Simon, Cagayan de Oro City. She is 55 years old. Rosenda is married and has three adult-age children. To make a living, Rosenda owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail store. The main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food and daily use products in the local community. Rosenda has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 4000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Rosenda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosenda is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Rosenda from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

location.town: San Simon, Cagayan de Oro, Misamis Oriental

loans.name: Elsa Marina

texts.es:
la señora Elsa Marina R. Marinez tiene 41 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene dos hijos que estan estudiando en el colegio. Elsa se dedica a la venta de comida y golosinas desde hace 10 años, su familia depende de ella no tiene casa propia, alquila un lugar para vivir.
Esta solicitando el credito para comprar mas ingredientes para fabricar sus golosinas y comidas y asi atender mejor a su clientela ya que en estos dias han estado llegando muchas personas en busca de comida y no esta cumpliendo con todas las exigencias de sus clientes. 
su deseo es que esta navidad sea de un tiempo de paz, amor y prosperidad
texts.en:
Señora Elsa Marina R. M. is 41 years old, is a single mother and has 2 children that study at college. She has worked selling food and sweets for 10 years, and her family depends on her. She doesn't own her own house, but rents a place to live. She is seeking a loan to buy more ingredients to make her sweets and food, and thereby better attend to her clientele now that many people are arriving in search of her food and she can't meet all the demands of her clients. Her dream is that this Christmas be a time of peace, love and prosperity.

Translated from Spanish by Jane McCrory, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy refreshments, chicken and pork meat, tortillas, vegetables, butter, salt, spices, beans, water, plates, disposable cups.

loans.name: Juan Alejo

texts.es: El señor Juan Alberto, tiene  41 años de edad, es casado y tiene dos hijos los cuales son menores de edad. El señor tiene la actividad económica de  un taller de carpintería. Este está ubicado en su vivienda. Dio inicio a su negocio hace 15 años con muy pocos materiales, influenciado en parte por sus familiares que se dedican a este negocio. El crédito será invertido en la compra de muebles ya que su negocio está ubicado en una zona de fácil acceso que le permite realizar la venta de sus muebles, por lo que vende más. por lo cual también aporta para el sustento del hogar. Su sueño siempre ha sido tener un taller grande el cual pueda abastecer a muchas personas y también brindar empleos.
texts.en:
Juan Alberto is 41 and married. He has two minor children. He has a carpenter’s shop that is located in his house. He started the business with very few materials 15 years ago. He was partially influenced by relatives in the same business. The loan is to buy furniture because his business is located in an area with easy access. This allows him to sell his furniture, which he sells the most. It also contributes to the support of his household. His dream has always been to have a large shop where he could serve a lot of people and also have employees.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn is a rice farmer. She currently owns a two-hectare rice field. At 35, she is married and has three children. Her oldest child is only 13 years of age. She works hard to be able to send them to school and to proviD. for her family’s needs. She hopes to grow her business someday. 

She asked for a loan of 8,000 Philippine pesos from CEVI, a Kiva partner, to help her business financially. The income she gets from the farm is really helpful to her whole family. With the loan she applied for, she will be able to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Pot

texts.en: Pot C. is a humble citizen who currently lives with other family members in a commune of Kampong Chhnang province. She is married with five school-aged children. Her husband helps to support the family by working as a district consultant adviser. Pot C. is a professional Khmer lecturer who earns a fixed salary of $3 per day to be used to feed her family. Beside this, the family cultivates rice during the farming season. In the past, Pot C. hired a cow to help plow her farmland.  She is seeking a loan to purchase an ox, so that she can plow the land without paying to rent a cow.

loans.use: To purchase an ox

loans.name: Seydou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Seydou D. est âgé de 43 ans et vit dans une famille polygame avec ses 6 enfants et ses deux femmes dans le quartier Banankabougou, sous préfecture de Fana, deuxième région administrative de la république du Mali.
Monsieur Seydou abandonna l’école en classe de sixième année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour se consacrer aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce de céréales. 
Seydou est très sollicité et jouit d’une grande notoriété dans les activités d’achat et de  vente de céréales.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  il est à son cinquième prêt individuel, après  avoir correctement  remboursés les quatre précédents.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 8 tonnes de céréales sèches (fonio, arachides, haricot, petit mil maïs). 
Il s’approvisionne sur place  à  Fana ville et dans les villages environnants à un prix abordable pour venir les revendre dans sa boutique sise au grand marché de Fana quand les articles auront de la valeur, à une clientèle composée de revendeurs venant des grandes villes.
Il espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 50.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour les dépenses de la famille et le reste investi dans les activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Seydou D. is 43 years old and lives in a polygamous family with his six children and two wives in the Banankabougou neighbourhood, part of the Fana sous-préfecture, in the second administrative region of the Republic of Mali. Mr. Seydou left school in the sixth grade (Mali education system) to embark on revenue-generating activities, in particular the commerce of cereals. Seydou is quite in demand and has acquired a solid reputation in buying and selling cereals. With an eye on satisfying his ever-increasing customer base, he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso MFI where he is at his fifth loan request, having correctly reimbursed the four previous ones. He wants to use this loan to buy eight tons of dry cereal (fonio, peanuts, beans, millet, and corn). He gets his supplies locally at reasonable prices, in the town of Fana and in surrounding villages, and resells them when the products have increased in value. His store is located at the major market of Fana, and his customers are mainly resellers from the large cities. He hopes to reach an average monthly profit of 50,000 FCFA, which will be used for family expenses and the remainder invested in his business.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: But cereals

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah G. is currently in the business of selling sugar and beer at home and is requesting a loan to stock more crates of beer to sell. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to open a bar. Sarah is 30 years old and is married to a soldier. She has four children and her children go to school. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To stock more crates of beer to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Margarita

texts.en: Margarita L. is from Barangay Buliwao, Quezon, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 40 years old, is married, and has three school-aged children. Margarita owns and operates a business planting and harvesting a variety of vegetables for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 7,000 PHP a month. In 2008, Margarita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizer such as manure. Margarita is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be her fourth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Olinda Ricardo

texts.pt:
Olinda Ricardo H. nasceu na Província de Inhambane, sul de Moçambique, tem 35 anos de idade, viúva e mãe de 2 filhos de 12 e 9 anos. Todos vão a escola, fez a 7ª classe teve que parar quando fica grávida do seu primeiro filho mas do momento esta a frequentar a 8ª classe. Vive na casa dos seus pais e não responsabiliza se por mais ninguém.

Sai da Província de Inhambane para o Distrito de Namaacha na Fronteira da Suazilândia com seus pais, onde inicia os estudos e interrompe quando junta se com seu esposo este que perde a vida deixando lhe com dois filhos. A vida de Olinda fica difícil devido a disputa da partilha de bens com os sogros, assim é expulsa de sua própria casa e passa a viver com seus progenitores, hoje trabalha no Hotel Li bombos como empregada de mesa (garsonete) há 16 anos trabalhando das 7h as 15h auferindo mensalmente 1.600.00mt que aplica nas dispersas da casa e não consegue poupar nenhum valor ao mês devido empréstimo que solicitou na HLUVUKU-ADSEMA para legalizar o terreno e construção da sua própria casa.
 
Nunca teve empréstimos em outros bancos, conhece a Hluvuku através do seu pai que também é cliente da HLUVUKU-ADSEMA. Este é o segundo empréstimo de Olinda na Hluvuku e primeiro com kiva no valor de 10.000.00mt com qual pretende comprar material de construção (carrada de areia, cimento e blocos) para dar inicio da sua obra. O empréstimo anterior foi de 5.000.00mt foi usado para legalizar o seu terreno.
texts.en:
Olinda Ricardo H. was born in Inhambane Province in southern Mozambique. She is 35 years old, widowed, and the mother of two children, ages 12 and 9. Both of them go to school. Olinda finished seventh grade. She had to quit when she became pregnant with her first child, but she is currently attending eighth grade. She lives in her parents' house and is not responsible for anyone else. She left Inhambane Province to go with her parents to Namaacha District on the border with Swaziland, where she began her studies, and stopped them when she married her husband, who passed away, leaving her with two children. Olinda's life was difficult owing to a dispute with her in-laws over property division, so she was kicked out of her own house and went to live with her parents. Today she works at the Hotel Li Bombos as a waitress. She has worked there for 16 years, working from 7:00 am until 3:00 pm and earning 1,600 meticais per month, which she uses for household expenses and cannot save anything, so she asked Hluvuku-Adsema for a loan to buy the title for her land and build a house on it. Olinda has never had loans from other banks. She learned about Hluvuku from her father, who is also a customer of Hluvuku-Adsema. This is her second loan from Hluvuku and her first with Kiva. She will use this loan of 10,000 meticais to buy construction materials (loads of sand, cement and blocks) to begin building her house. The earlier loan of 5,000 meticais was used to buy the title to her land.

Translated from Portuguese by Danielle Maxson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Construction materials

loans.name: Thoeun

texts.en: Mrs. Thoeun U., who lives in Ta Preah village in Takeo province, was born in 1966. She owns a general store in the local village and she is a pig breeder also. Since her business is going well she wants to expand it. So to improve breeding pigs, Mrs. Thoeun U. is asking for a loan to buy some piglets and pig food for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Bauch Kun, is a farmer who owns two hectares of land to cultivate rice to sell to support his family and he is a white wine maker also. Through this activity, this couple supports three children. Two of the children are enrolled in the local public school, and the youngest one is five years old.

loans.use: To buy some piglets and pig food

loans.name: Ruel

texts.en: Ruel E. is from the village of San Jose. He is 28 years old, is married, and has one infant child. Ruel owns and operates a business planting and harvesting rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over ten years and earns approximately 40,000 PHP per harvest. In 2006, Ruel joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and his ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Ruel is requesting a new loan of 25,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. This loan will be his eighth from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand his business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise

loans.name: Marleny

texts.es: Marleny, de 23 años, es madre soltera y mantiene a  sus dos hijos pequeños. Juntos viven en una comunidad ubicada en la selva cuzqueña, donde tienen su casa propia hecha a base de madera.Asegura que aprendió a trabajar desde muy pequeña, y cuando salio embarazada continuo trabajando  porque quería sacar adelante a su primer hijo, y  tuvo el respaldo de toda su familia. Los 3 años siguientes trabajo para su padre, a la vez aprendía las técnicas de sembrío y cosecha, es por ello que  con el pasar del tiempo, su padre le obsequio una pequeña parcela para que pueda labrar y producir su propio cacao y café, y las ganancias solo le alcanzaban para colaborar con la canasta familiar. En la actualidad tiene una tienda de abarrotes, y además continúa con la venta de sus productos agrícolas. Su punto de venta lo realiza en su casa, y; por lo general cuenta con la ayuda de sus hijos. Todos los días empieza su jornada a las 6 de la mañana, y atiende hasta las 10 de la noche. Para el futuro anhela ampliar su tienda de abarrotes, para introducir nuevos productos en busca del progreso  de su negocio.Este es el segundo crédito con MFP, y  se compromete en  seguir cumpliendo con sus obligaciones de pago, además se siente reconfortada  con su banco comunal, por lo beneficios que le otorga.Marleny tiene planeado invertir  el dinero solicitado  en la compra de  mercadería que necesita para abastecer su tienda de abarrotes, porque busca seguir  progresando.
texts.en:
Marleny is 23 years old and a single mother with two small children. They live together in a community located in the jungles of Cuzco, where they have their own wooden house. She learned to work when she was very young and when she became pregnant, she continued working because she wanted to give her first child a better life and because she had the support of her family. For the next three years, she worked for her father and learned the techniques for planting and harvesting. As such, after some time, her father gave her a small plot so that she could farm and produce her own cacao and coffee, but her earnings were only enough to cover some of her family's basic necessities. Nowadays, she has a grocery store and also continues to sell her agricultural products. She sells her items from her home and mostly relies on the help of her children. Every day, she begins work at 6 o'clock in the morning until 10 at night. In the future, she hopes to expand her store by introducing new products. This is her second credit with MFP and she promises to continue to make her payments. In addition, she feels comforted by her communal bank for the benefits that they offer her. Marleny plans to invest the money that she has applied for in the purchase of merchandise that she needs to stock her store with because she wants to keep progressing.

Translated from Spanish by Tracy Quan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her business.

loans.name: Antoinette

texts.en:
Madame Antoinette C. is 28 years old and works selling charcoal out of her home in Lome. She is married to a tennis player and they have two children. 

Madame C. sells charcoal in order to make money. She has had this business since 2006. She usually is able to purchase the charcoal up north in the interior of Togo, but to ease her burden this month she has requested a microloan of 150,000 Communauté Financière Africaine Francs in order to purchase more charcoal. This is her first time taking a loan from WAGES, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To purchase charcoal to sell

loans.name: Sabougnouman  3 Group

texts.fr:
Les dix  membres du groupe Sabougnouman  3 sont des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 40 ans et 3 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames à Fatiana, un des villages de la préfecture de Dioïla, région de Koulikoro, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but de pouvoir mieux organiser leurs activités en début d’hivernage. 
Les spéculations cultivées sont entre autres l’arachide,   le petit mil et le haricot. Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt de campagne et le premier a été bien remboursé.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, CECILE T. compte acheter les intrants avant la hausse des prix, les petits équipements et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir environs 1 hectare d’arachide et du haricot.
Les productions sont vendues au niveau de la ville de Dioïla et Fana après les récoltes à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 30000FCFA en fin de  campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the Sabougnouman 3 group are married women, who average 40 years of age with three children each. The majority of them live in polygamous families in Fatiana, one of the villages of the prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region, which is the second administrative region of Mali. They are collaborating with the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with the aim of better organising their activities at the beginning of the winter season. The crops they cultivate include peanuts, pearl millet and beans. They are on their second farming loan, and the first was paid on time. With this new loan, Cecile T. is planning to buy intrants before the price increases and small equipment, as well as paying the labor costs of maintaining around a hectare of peanuts and beans. The produce, once harvested, is sold in the towns of Dioïla and Fana, to a customer base made up of men and women. The women are expecting to make an average profit of 30,000FCFA at the end of the season.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of intrants and small farming equipment, as well as labor costs

loans.name: Lucina

texts.en:
Lucina B. is from the town of Trento. She is 42 years old. Lucina is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Lucina owns and operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Lucina also raises pigs and chickens. She hopes that this new venture of hers will grow as well.

Lucina joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lucina has successfully repaid a previous loan from CEVI. Lucina is requesting a new loan of 6,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase fertilizers, such as manure, and livestock feed. This loan will be the second loan taken out by Lucina from CEVI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. 

About CEVI:

Community Economic Ventures, Inc (CEVI) has increased its portfolio significantly over the recent years.  Based in Bohol, they have numerous branches throughout the Philippines.  In 2009, CEVI was awarded a CGAP silver award for transparency in social performance monitoring.  CEVI not only provides credit for its clients but also savings, insurance and training, which are provided through regular cluster group meetings.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and livestock feed

loans.name: Dialyn

texts.en:
Dialyn P. lives in the village of Turod, Quezon. She is 26 years old, married and has three school-aged children. For the last two years, she has made a living running a local  convenience store where she sells snacks and candy to people who live in her community.  She earns about 3,000 PHP a month from her work.

Earlier this year, Dialyn joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She is applying for her first loan, for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to buy more items to sell to her customers. She plans to use the additional income made possible by this loan to expand and improve her business. 

About ASKI:
ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern parts of the country. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to buy additional products to sell to her customers

loans.name: Mwanaharusi

texts.en:
Mwanaharusi has been selling khangas and kikois (a piece of colored cloth used as clothing and wrapped around the waist and legs or shoulders) for 4 years. She is a married woman with three children and is expecting a fourth one. Her children attend school.

She visits the nearby town to purchase khangas at a wholesale price. The khanga is a dress that is mostly won by the coastal women who are her major customers. She sells khangas door-to-door. With the Kshs. 40,000 loan, Mwanaharusi wants to diversify her business by buying clothes for both ladies and men. 

One of her greatest challenges is transportation of the khangas from the town. Her husband supports her when the business goes down.

She owns her home which has both electricity and water. She cites her greatest monthly expenses as school fees.  In the coming years, Mwanaharusi hopes to own a shop and purchase khangas and clothes in larger quantities.

loans.use: Clothes for both ladies and men

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Norma P. is from the town of Banga. She is 60 years old, married and has 5 adult children. Norma owns & operates an agricultural business, planting and harvesting rice for sale. She also raises hogs for fattening and sale and runs a small sari-sari store where she sells a variety of products.

Norma joined CEVI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan  from CEVI. She is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase farm inputs, pigfeed and additional store inventory. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve the general living conditions of her family.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs, pigfeed and additional store inventory

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.es: Rosalía tiene 62 años, es una madre de familia muy noble y trabajadora, vive en su casa propia  en compañía de su esposo y sus 4 hijos. Con mucho esfuerzo, Rosalía prepara los condimentos para sazonar sus anticuchos, luego que cayera enferma varios días, dejó de atender su negocio. Es así que viene desafiando las adversidades de su salud, ya que no le gusta, estar sin hacer nada.  En la actualidad busca el apoya de su sobrina, quien atiende ahora su público, de ese modo continua con su negocio de anticuchos, que son platillos muy solicitados por sus clientes. Su negocio se encuentra bien ubicado, en la puerta de su casa, lugar donde circulan mucha gente y eso le favorece mucho en las ganancias. En adelante, piensa diversificar su negocio instalando una panadería, sin embargo debe restaurar el techo de su casa. Este su segundo crédito con MFP; y se compromete en pagar las cuotas estipuladas. Asimismo manifiesta haberse integrado a su grupo comunal y se lleva bien con todos sus compañeros. Con el crédito que solicita, comprará una parrilla, donde pueda freír todos sus anticuchos de manera más rápida.
texts.en:
Rosalia, 62, is a mother from an honest and hard-working family. She lives in her own home alongside her husband and their 4 children. With a great deal of effort, Rosalia prepares seasonings to flavour skewered meats. 

After falling ill for several days she had to shut down her business. She has since been defying the hardships derived from her health, because she does not like to be idle. At the moment, her niece helps her by serving the customers. That's how Rosalia has managed to continue her swekered meats business. Her dishes are very much in demand and her business is well located, on her doorstep, with a lot of traffic, which helps her earnings very much. In future she would like to diversify her business by installing a bakery, but first she must restore the roof of her house. 

This is her second loan with MFP, and she is comitted to repaying it as agreed. She also explains that she has fit into her loan group very well and that she gets on fine with all other members. With the requested loan she plans to buy a grill, so she can fry the skewered meat more quickly.

loans.use: Buy a grill.

loans.name: Kamukamu Women's Group - Kyenjojo

texts.en:
Hardworking Resty S. is a married mother of five children. She has been running a tea-growing business in Kitoma, Kyenjojo, for more than 25 years. It all began when she bought a plantation garden of tea leaves and since then, she has been picking green tea leaves and selling them to the Mabale tea factory. She does this alongside sales from fresh foods like cassava and sweet potatoes. She makes 30,000 Ugandan shillings in a week.

For now, she is held back by poor yields and therefore, she is seeking a loan that will help her buy fertilizers for her to improve the quality of her land and her yields. This will, in the long run, help her get more sales revenue out of selling her tea leaves and she says she will be able to pay tuition fees for her university-going children. Kamukamu is the group she belongs to.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en:
Agnes is a married, 41-year-old woman. She and her husband have seven children who are between the ages of 3 and 20 years old. Five of their children are currently attending school. She has been farming for ten years in Kisii town, which is located in western Kenya. Her farm produces maize, vegetables, bananas, and tea, all of which she sells locally.

She is requesting this loan in the amount of 30,000 KES ($375) through Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and raise a dairy cow. The expected increase in income from the sale of milk will help her improve the family's standard of living. Her biggest challenge is a lack of funding, which is needed to buy farm products like fertilizers and seeds. She plans to acquire more dairy cows in future. She explains that she is grateful to Juhudi for the rural-based projects, which help the needy people in her area.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing a dairy cow.

loans.name: Egidia

texts.en:
Egidia is 40 years old. She is married and has five children between the ages of 7 and 15. All her children go to school. Her husband works as a taxi driver. Egidia sells food stuffs such as beans and sorghum. From this loan she will buy more beans and sorghum to sell.  With the profit from this business she will buy goats for rearing. 

Egidia says that this business has helped in solving various issues concerning the family. In the future she would like to divert from this business and set up her own shop.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 27-year-old single woman living with her parents. She is from Lebanon. She has been working in a clothing shop in her town for five years. In 2008, she opened her own shop. With her business income, she helps her father who works as a farmer, to cover the family expenses. She displays women's and children's clothes in her shop. 

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1000 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l. to expand her store’s inventory of new collections. The diversity of her merchandise selection will help her increase her sales and therefore her income. In the future, she is hoping also to sell shoes in her store. Currently, she mostly sells clothes.

loans.use: to expand her store’s inventory of new collections

loans.name: Guillermina

texts.es:
La solicitante es la Sr. Guillermina R.  la misma es casada  se dedica a la venta y elaboración de comidas  posee casa propia con todas las comodidades necesarias de un hogar en el  Barrio Santa Rosa se dedica a la elaboración de bocaditos  hace mas de 10 años  tiene una buena  clientela formada.
La Señora Guillermina es una persona muy trabajadora y gracias a la actividad que realiza ha podido salir adelante e ir creciendo en su micro Empresa.
  Este crédito no es el primero que recibe de la Fundación Paraguaya, y en esta ocasión solicita el préstamo para la compra de que los insumos que utiliza para la elaboración de comidas como carne, discos para la empanadas, verduras, condimentos, y otros.
texts.en:
This applicant is Sra. Guillermina R.. She is married and earns her living by preparing and selling food. Guillermina has her own home with all the necessary comforts in the Santa Rosa neighborhood. She has been preparing snacks for more than ten years and has a well-established customer base.

Sra. Guillermina is a hardworking individual. Thanks to this activity, she has been able to get ahead and grow her small business.

This loan is not the first she has received from Fundación Paraguaya. On this occasion, she is requesting funds to buy supplies for preparing food such as meat, empanada wrappers, vegetables, condiments, and other items.

loans.use: Purchase meat, empanada wrappers, vegetables, condiments, and other items

loans.name: Ana Julia

texts.es: Ana es una mujer muy emprendedora y que ha sabido salir adelante ante circunstancias muy difíciles. Ella tiene 2 hijos menores de edad a su cargo, su actividad es una pulpería y venta de cosméticos. Hace más de 7 años que tiene este negocio, sabe que tiene la obligación de sacar adelante a sus hijos que son el futuro de su familia. Ella dio inicio a este negocio por la necesidad de proveer el alimento diario a su hogar, ya que además en su comarca no hay mucha competencia es por eso  que ella se preocupa por proporcionar un buen servicio. El motivo del crédito es para la compra de golosinas, granos básicos, refrescos, jugos, detergentes entres otras cosas necesarias en el hogar.
texts.en:
Ana is a very enterprising woman who has known how to get ahead when faced with very difficult circumstances.  She has two dependent children in her care. 

Ana's business is a grocery store and she also sells cosmetics.  She has had her business for more than 7 years.  She knows that it is her duty to get her children ahead in life as they are the future of her family.  She started this business out of necessity as she needed to provide food for her household.  There isn't a lot of competition in her area but she works hard to provide good customer service.

Ana will use her loan to buy candy, basic grains, soft drinks, juices, detergents and other necessary household products.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Benkadi sont de femmes mariées, elles ont en moyenne 28 ans, 3 enfants et vivent avec leurs maris et enfants dans des familles traditionnelles élargies dans le village de Coulibalyla, préfecture de Dioïla, Région de Koulikoro (deuxième région  administrative de la république du Mali).
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de parenté, de voisinage et font le commerce de poisson, de condiments et de l’arachide.                                                                                     
Les femmes du groupe Benkadi sont à leur premier prêt solidaire.                                                                          
FATOUMATA C., la présidente du groupe compte  s’approvisionne quotidiennement en poissons fumés avec les revendeurs de Dioïla. Elle effectue ses ventes sur place au village et pendant les jours de foires au marché de Dioïla, au comptant et à crédit, à une clientèle composée de femmes et d’hommes.
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 15 000F CFA qui sera utilisé pour payer le prêt, et effectuer les dépenses personnelles.
texts.en:
The members of the Benkadi solidarity group are married women who average 28 years of age and three children each. They live with their husbands and children in extended traditional families in the village of Coulibalyla, prefecture of Dioïla, in the Koulikoro region (second administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

They know one another as neighbors and through ties of kinship. They sell fish, condiments and peanuts. The Benkadi group members are on their first loan.

Fatoumata C., president of the group, gets her daily stocks of smoked fish from the resellers of Dioïla. She sells on location, in the village, and on fair days at the Dioïla market, for cash and credit to a customer base of both men and women.

She expects to earn a monthly profit of 15,000 FCFA, which she will use to repay the loan and for personal expenses.

loans.use: Buying smoked fish

loans.name: Verónica Paola

texts.es:
En la ciudadela San Jorge de la ciudad de Portoviejo, ciudad hermosa de verdes  montañas y paisajes  encantadores, encontramos el lugar donde se reúnen cada quince días las socias del Banco Comunal San Jorge.
 
En este lugar conocimos a la señora Verónica, ella tiene  39 años de edad, es madre soltera de cuatro  hijos, una mayor y tres de 16, 11 y 9 años de edad, todos aun viven con ella y estudian en Universidad, colegio y escuela. Tiene casa propia en la que vive junto a sus queridos hijos. Está en el Banco Comunal hace 7 años y le gusta porque siempre le han ayudado con los créditos.

Se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo, su forma de  ventas es puerta a puerta, también vende en su  casa hasta donde llegan sus clientes cuando ella compra mercadería nueva, nos cuenta que sus  clientes le hacen muchos pedidos ya que trae mercadería de buena calidad. Trabaja todos los días en las tardes, deja a crédito a sus clientes  y cobra cada quince días. Su mercadería  la va a comprar a Guayaquil cada quince días o al mes de acuerdo a lo que necesite.

Este crédito es para comprar la  ropa más que todo ropa de mujer, pantalones, blusas, interiores, entre otras prendas. Sus sueños son terminar su casa que aun la tiene en construcción.
texts.en:
In the community of San Jorge within the beautiful city of Portoviejo there are green mountains and enchanting landscapes. The members of the San Jorge Communal Bank meet in this place every fifteen days.

It is here one can find Sra. Verónica. She is 39 years old and a single mother with four children. Her oldest child is an adult and the other three are 16, 11, and 9 years of age. All of them live with her and study at the university, high school, and elementary school. She has her own home where she lives with her beloved children. Verónica has been with her Communal Bank for seven years and has always enjoyed it because she has received help through the loans.

She sells all types of clothing door to door. In addition, she sells from her house where her customers come whenever she acquires new merchandise. Verónica says her customers place many orders because she always obtains merchandise of good quality. She works every day in the afternoons. Verónica extends credit to her customers and collects every fifteen days. She travels to Guayaquil to buy her merchandise every fifteen days or monthly based on necessity.

This loan will be used to buy more clothing of all types such as women’s outfits, trousers, blouses, undergarments, and other items. Her dream is to finish her house which is under construction.

loans.use: Purchase women's clothing, trousers, blouses, undergarments, and other items

loans.name: Rossel

texts.en:
Rossel B. is from the village of Tupsan, Mahinog, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old. Rossel is married and has five school-aged children. To make a living, she owns and operates a business of buying and selling coconuts for copras (dried coconut meat used for oil production) in the local community. Rossel has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately $125 a month for these activities.

In 2010, Rossel joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.
